questions.text: In which of the following time periods during the course of a disease would it be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient?
questions.solution:
The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time, which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the given image. It is during this time period in course of the disease, it would be beneficial to administer a screening test to a patient.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

The usual time of diagnosis (point 3): The onset of symptoms is followed by a short interval (varies from disease to disease) after which the patient presents to a healthcare setup, where a diagnosis of the disease is made. Based on treatment and prognosis, the patient can progress to either recovery, disability, or death. 

In the image, the period between the first possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time and is represented by the time period between points 1 and 3 in the image. Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Natural history of disease: It refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment.

Exposure: The disease process begins with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host. For example in infectious disease, the exposure is a microorganism. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibers or components in tobacco smoke.

Pathological changes: After the disease process has been triggered, pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it. This stage of subclinical disease, extending from the time of exposure to the onset of symptoms, is usually called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases. During this stage, the disease remains asymptomatic.

The onset of clinical symptoms: It is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.

The below diagram shows the natural history of disease in an individual over time.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A 30-year old chronic smoker presented with a history of dry cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and recurrent pneumothoraces over the past few months. An HRCT report showed multiple nodules and cysts. The lung biopsy appears as below. Which of the following is a characteristic electron microscopic finding for this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhan cells with folded nuclei is suggestive of adult pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Birbeck granules are the characteristic election microscopy finding seen in this disease.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in older children, adults
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include:

  • Often asymptomatic
  • Dyspnea, cough, bone pain, an abnormal growth of soft tissue over the affected bone, rash, pruritus, increased thirst, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Fatigue, generalized weakness, weight loss, night sweats, nausea, and fever may also occur.

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhan cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy. The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Diagnosis is confirmed by a biopsy of the lesion. Spontaneous regression is seen in asymptomatic lesions and after cessation of smoking in pulmonary LCH. Symptomatic cases are managed with intralesional steroid injection, low-dose radiotherapy, and curettage of the lesion. Multiagent chemotherapy is indicated for multisystemic disease.

 

Other options:

Rosenthal fibres are eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions seen in pilocytic astrocytomas.

Fried-egg appearance is seen in sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm seen in oligodendrogliomas.

Corps ronds are rounded dyskeratotic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm in the epidermis  seen in Darier's disease. Corps grains are small cells with shrunken cytoplasm, also seen in association with corps ronds.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels will not be affected due to an embolus originating in the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Inferior gluteal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, and hence, would not be affected due to an embolus from the posterior division of internal iliac artery. 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

questions.text: A 50-year old man, who is a known case of HIV, presented with features suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

choices.text: Do 2 sputum smears and chest X-Ray
Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV, who is suspected to have tuberculosis, CBNAAT is ordered upfront.

For people living with HIV (PLHIV), CBNAAT has to be done from the sputum specimen or specimen from the appropriate extrapulmonary site. If CBNAAT linkage is unavailable, then microscopy and chest-X ray is done on the same day.

Two sputum samples are sent for cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification (CBNAAT) which, within 2 hours, detects the presence of Mycobacterium DNA along with resistance against rifampicin. It analyses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens) using real-time PCR technology. CBNAAT is also ordered upfront in case of children or extrapulmonary tuberculosis. 

In PLHIV, there are increased chances of sputum negative TB and fewer chances of cavitation in a chest x-ray. Hence, CBNAAT is preferred.

Line probe assays (LPA) are ordered to look for drug resistance. First-line LPA detects resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid while second-line LPA detects resistance to fluoroquinolones and injectable second-line drugs.

In a patient with HIV and TB, start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated by the patient (between 2 weeks and 2 months). This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

questions.text:
From the given prescription of spectacles, which of the following are examples of simple, myopic with-the-rule astigmatism?
  1. -1DS with +2DC at 180o
  2. -1DS with +1DC at 90o
  3. +2DC at 90o
  4. -1DS with -1DC at 90o
  5. -1DC at 180o
questions.solution:
Among the above options, ii and v are the correct examples for simple myopic astigmatism with-the-rule.  

Simple myopic astigmatism is where the rays of light form two focal points one before the retina and one on the retina. When the two principal meridians of light rays are placed at right angles to one
another but the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal, it is called with-the-rule astigmatism. 

Options - 

A. -1D is the power of the sphere on the vertical and horizontal axis. With cylindrical correction of +2D at 180o, it acts along the vertical axis (since the cylindrical correction always acts in the axis perpendicular to it). Thus, the resultant is:

Power in the vertical axis = -1 plus +2 = +1D 

Power in the horizontal axis = -1D

This is an example of mixed astigmatism. 

 

B. -1D is the power of the sphere on the vertical and horizontal axis. Here, +1D correction of cylindrical acts horizontally. Thus, the resultant power in the:

Vertical axis = -1D

Horizontal axis = -1 plus +1 = 0

Since myopia has higher power than emmetropia, the power in the vertical axis is more than in the horizontal. Thus, this is an example of simple myopic with-the-rule astigmatism. 

 

C. +2DC power of the cylindrical indicates hypermetropia. 

D. Resultant power in the horizontal axis here is = -1 plus -1 = -2D

Vertical axis = -1D.

This is an example of a compound, myopic against-the-rule astigmatism. 

 

E. Here, the power of the cylindrical (-1DC) is seen only along one axis. Hence, it is simple myopic astigmatism. Since the power acts vertically, the vertical axis has more power than the horizontal one, following the with-the-rule mechanism.

questions.text: Tonsillectomy can be  performed in:

choices.text: Child with an impaired palatal function

questions.solution:
Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

Three general categories of contraindications exist and they are:

  1. Velopharyngeal,
  2. Hematologic
  3. Infectious.
  4. Miscellaneous

1. Velopharyngeal

  • Overt cleft palate
  • Submucous cleft palate
  • Impaired palatal function

2. Hematologic

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukemia, purpura, aplastic anemia or hemophilia.

3. Infectious

  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.

4. Miscellaneous

  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: FFA picture shows the following. The most likely diagnosis based on the image is
questions.solution:
The image depicts smoke stack pattern in FFA. This is characteristically seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Fundus fluorescein angiography helps in confirming the diagnosis of CSR.

Two patterns are seen :

  • Ink-blot pattern: It consists of small hyperfluorescent spot which gradually increases in size.
  • Smoke-stack pattern: It consists of a small hyperfluorescent spot which ascends vertically like a smoke-stack and gradually spreads laterally to take a mushroom or umbrella configuration.

Image below shows Ink-blot appearance.

The image below shows the following charectaristic appearances:

  • Image A - Cystoid macular edema - Petaloid appearance
  • Image B - Central serous retinopathy - Smoke stack pattern
  • Image C - Drusen - Stars in the sky appearance
  • Image D - Macular Ischemia - enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non perfused areas.

questions.text:
Match the condition with the anatomic structure affected:
Column A Column B
1. Boxer's elbow A. Olecranon process
2. Little leaguer's elbow B. Medial epicondyle
3. Nursemaid's elbow C. Olecranon bursa
4. Student's elbow D. Radial head
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option B 

1. Boxer's elbow A. Olecranon Process
2. Little leaguer's elbow B. Medial epicondyle
3. Nursemaid's elbow D. Radial head
4. Student's elbow C. Olecranon bursa

Boxer's elbow occurs in boxers due to repetitive valgus hyperextension while jabbing. As a result, there is impingement of olecranon, hence it is also known as olecranon impingement syndrome or hyperextension overload syndrome.

Little leaguer's elbow occurs when there is an avulsion fracture of the medial epicondyle. It is more commonly seen in throwing sports playing children and adolescents. 

Student’s elbow (Olecranon bursitis/ Miner's elbow / Draughtsman elbow) involves the olecranon bursa. It occurs most commonly because of trauma, sepsis, and inflammatory arthritis.

 Nursemaid’s Elbow (Radial head subluxation) involves the displacement of the radial head. It occurs when axial traction on a pronated forearm with the elbow in extension. This causes the annular ligament to slip over the radial head and gets trapped in the radiohumeral joint.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with a history of nasal congestion, nasal blockage, facial pain, and hyposmia for the past year. A CT was done based on the suspicion of chronic rhinosinusitis and it revealed differential hyperattenuating areas within the sinuses. All of the following constitute minor criteria to confirm the diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of chronic rhinosinusitis along with the CT finding of differential hyperattenuating areas within the sinuses points towards a diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis. Type I hypersensitivity is a major diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis and the others are part of the minor criterion.

Bent and Kuhn proposed the diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis, which is considered the standard diagnostic criteria to date. This includes:

Major criteria:

  1. Type I hypersensitivity 
  2. Nasal polyposis
  3. Characteristic CT findings
  4. Eosinophilic mucin without invasion
  5. Positive fungal stain

Minor criteria:

  1. Asthma
  2. Unilateral disease
  3. Bone erosion
  4. Fungal cultures
  5. Charcot-Leyden crystals
  6. Serum eosinophilia

All the major criteria must be met by the patient while the minor criteria serve to support the diagnosis and describe individual patients.

Treatment:

  • Avoidance of contact with allergens
  • Treating the allergy with antihistamines and corticosteroid nasal sprays
  • Aggressive surgery to remove the eosinophilic mucin and promote adequate sinus drainage
  • Oral corticosteroids can also be given post-surgery
  • At present, immunotherapy directed against both fungal and non-fungal allergens are under clinical trials

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of seizures and intermittent loss of consciousness. The MRI image of the brain is shown. Which of the following drug regulatory schedules does the drug of choice for this condition belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of seizures and the radiological findings of multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulose). Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. It belongs to schedule H according to the drug regulatory schedules.

Schedule H deals with prescription drugs. All the drugs listed under schedule H should be provided to the patient only with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. 

All the drugs under the list must have the warning mentioned below, on their packaging listed prominently. 

"Schedule H drug. Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner only" 

Schedule H1: To be sold on the production of a valid prescription, but the chemist will maintain a separate register where the identity of the patient, contact details of the prescribing doctor, and the name and dispensed quantity of the drug will be recorded. The dispensing quantity should be strictly according to the valid prescription. It is a recently introduced list with the objective of curtailing indiscriminate use of antimicrobials. 

Schedule X: To be sold with a valid prescription. Prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist. The drugs that have high abuse liability are included in schedule X.

 

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule Details
Schedule C Biological and other special products e.g. Toxins, Insulin, Sera & Antibiotics.
Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.
Schedule F

Blood and blood products

F I - Production of Bacterial vaccines, Anti- Sera

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation
Schedule G With a label of Caution, dangerous to use except under medical supervision.
Schedule H Prescription drugs.
Schedule J List of diseases that a drug may not prevent or cure. Eg - HIV & Atherosclerosis
Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices
Schedule P Regulations regarding the life period and storage of various drugs.
Schedule W Drugs marketed under generic names.
Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.
Schedule Y Requirement and guidelines for import/ manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the dermatology clinic with the following lesions over both the legs. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the given disease?

choices.text: Linear deposits of IgA at the dermal-epidermal junction
The major target antigen is the ectodomain of BP210
Cluster of jewels sign is not pathognomic to this disease
Dapsone and corticosteroids are part of the first line treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year old child with the lesions shown in the given image in a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘cluster of jewels’ sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease. The main target antigens seen in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2.

Linear IgA disease/chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) is an immunobullous disease of childhood that clinically can present as an annular arrangement of vesicles. It arises more abruptly in children compared to adults. It has a bimodal onset, below the age of 5 years and between the age of 60 - 65 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Mucous membrane lesions like oral erosions and ulcers are commonly seen. Nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.
  • Tense blisters, vesicles and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, resembling a crown/cluster of jewels or a string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and perineum.
  • In adults, the distribution is over the extensors and the trunk.

Note: The ‘string of pearls’ or ‘cluster of jewels’ sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease and not pathognomic to this disease. 

The image below shows a string of pearls appearance in the Linear IgA disease.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Infections
  • Trauma
  • Vaccination
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Drugs like:
    • Vancomycin
    • Penicillin
    • NSAIDs

The main target antigens in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2 much more than BP230 or BPAg1.The mechanism of blister formation is due to the subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis forming microabscesses. 

The image given below shows subepidermal blister formation and neutrophils infiltrate in the papillary dermis.

The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Management involves:

  • First line:
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids with or without prednisolone
  • Second line:
    • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine being alternatives for dapsone.
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like oxytetracycline, doxycycline with or without nicotinamide
  • Third line:
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to have excessive urinary glucose levels. However, her blood glucose levels were normal. Further investigations revealed high levels of only L-xylulose in the urine. A genetic defect in which of the following pathways is most likely?
questions.solution:
High levels of L-xylulose in urine point to a diagnosis of essential pentosuria. It is a benign condition caused due to a defect in the uronic acid pathway.

Essential pentosuria has no clinical consequences. However, it can give false-positive results when urinary glucose is measured using alkaline copper reagents (Benedict’s test).

The lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway leads to essential Pentosuria. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine. Xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict's test positive. Bial's test is positive as xylulose is a pentose.

Essential pentosuria is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes :

  • Pentosuria
  • Albinism
  • Cystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: The test below depicts the presence of which of the following defect in the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the uncover test. There is the abduction of the left eye on uncovering it (refixation movement is abduction) which suggests left esophoria. 

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates on a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria

Adduction

(Nasal recovery)

 Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward Hyperphoria
Upward Hypophoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery are noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotopia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotopic/ Heterotopia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Classification of Strabismus 

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

 

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: A child who was being evaluated for hypertyrosinemia is diagnosed with Richner-Hanhart syndrome. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the likely cause of hypertyrosinemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase.

It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability.Untreated patients have marked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal, as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.

questions.text: The deformity shown in the following image is characteristically seen in ___________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg), which is characteristically seen in rickets.

However, it may also be seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text:
A 40-year old chronic smoker, with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, presented with epigastric pain, fatigue, and weight loss. He was found to have pallor, glossitis, and angular cheilosis. Peripheral smear appears as below. Serum antibodies to intrinsic factor are positive. Which of the following findings are characteristically associated with the underlying disease?
  1. Achlorhydria
  2. Neuroendocrine cell hypoplasia
  3. Hypogastrinemia
  4. Reduced pepsinogen levels
  5. Lymphocytic infiltrate
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pernicious anemia, secondary to autoimmune gastritis. Achlorhydria, reduced pepsinogen levels and lymphocytic infiltrate are some of the characteristics of autoimmune gastritis.

Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. It causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa, within the body and fundus and accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis. CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+, K+ - ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis.

Other characteristic features seen in autoimmune gastritis:

  • Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor
  • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
  • Hypergastrinemia
  • Endocrine cell hyperplasia → Carcinoid tumors
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia)
  • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)

The image below shows intestinal metaplasia with replacement of the surface, foveolar, and glandular epithelium in the oxyntic or antral mucosa (or both) by the intestinal epithelium, which is easily recognized by the presence of goblet cells.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:
  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of the vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factors.

Due to the neutralization of the intrinsic factor, there is decreased absorption of vitamin B12. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells), and the peripheral blood displays megaloblastic anemia. This is due to an impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anemia include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

Peripheral smear shows the following findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

Bone marrow shows the following findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Sieve like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

Increased risk of gastric cancer exists with chronic autoimmune atrophic gastritis. Parenteral/oral high dose Vitamin B12 can cure the neurological aspect of the disease while the risk of cancer and the changes to the gastric mucosa are unaffected.

questions.text: A 1-month-old male baby was brought to you with complaints of a left-sided flank mass. The mother reported that the child cries while urinating and had been treated with antibiotics for urinary tract infection. Ultrasonography was done and revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system, with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the ultrasonograph showing hydronephrosis of the affected kidney indicate a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) associated with UTI.

Hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound; it can, however, be transient or mild and resolves on its own. Re-evaluation should be done after birth and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and in cases of failure to thrive.

If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness. It needs to be ascertained whether the other kidney is involved, the lower ureter is dilated, the bladder wall is thickened, and whether emptying of the bladder is incomplete. Based on these findings, a diagnosis can be made.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Other options:

Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis after UPJ obstruction. In vesicoureteric reflux, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective; hence, abnormal backflow of urine occurs from the bladder into the ureter. It may also present with hydronephrosis; however, the distal ureter is also involved, unlike in this case.

Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. Since the distal urinary tract is normal-looking in this case, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. As a result, bilateral hydronephrosis and bladder dilatation is seen, unlike the unilateral involvement in this case.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: FDA has recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to the first oral antiviral drug combination for the treatment of COVID-19. This drug combination contains nirmatrelvir and ritonavir. What is the mechanism of action of nirmatrelvir?

choices.text: Inhibitor of RNA dependant RNA polymerase

questions.solution:
FDA recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to a combination of nirmatrelvir and ritonavir tablets (Paxlovid) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID-19. It is the first oral antiviral for the treatment of COVID-19.

Nirmatrelvir is a peptidomimetic inhibitor of the SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro). Inhibition of this enzyme makes the virus incapable of processing polyprotein precursors and thus prevents viral replication.

Ritonavir is an HIV-1 protease inhibitor. It inhibits the CYP3A-mediated metabolism of nirmatrelvir which results in increased plasma concentrations of nirmatrelvir. It is not active against SARS-CoV-2 Mpro.

Patients who tested positive with direct SARS-CoV-2 test can be administered this drug combination, provided they are:

  • 12 years of age and older
  • Weighing at least 40 kgs
  • At high risk for progression to severe COVID-19.

Contraindications include hypersensitivity reactions to the active ingredients or any other components, co-administration with drugs highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance, co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers. Adverse reactions include dysgeusia, diarrhea, hypertension, and myalgia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.

Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.

Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows the histopathological image of FSGS.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency in an unresponsive state. There is an alleged history of consumption of multiple prescription tablets in an attempt to commit suicide. After the drug was conclusively identified, the doctor recommends dialysis for definitive management. The drug most likely is:
questions.solution:
The drug most likely is lithium as it is the only one amongst the given drugs that can be removed by dialysis. It is the treatment of choice in case of severe lithium toxicity (>4mEq/L). 

The distribution of lithium is mainly restricted to the vascular compartment and it is not bound to any plasma proteins. Dialysis is effective in removing the drugs if they are sufficiently present in the free form in the plasma. Therefore, lithium can be removed by dialysis during an overdose.

Drugs not suitable for dialysis are those with:

  • High volume of distribution - digoxin, verapamil, and organophosphates 
  • High level of plasma protein binding - diazepam 

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

questions.text:
Match the following methods of postcoital contraception to their doses.
Method Dose
1. Plan B A. Two 60 mg tablets to be taken at an interval of 12 hours 
2. Yuzpe B. 100µg ethinyl estradiol and 0.5 mg of Levonorgestrel, 2 tablets given 12 hours apart
3. Centchroman C. One 30 mg tablet 
4. Ulipristal D. Two 0.75mg tablets to be taken stat and after 12 hours 
5. Plan B-one step
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C.

Methods of Emergency contraception

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel (Plan B single step) 1.5mg tablet stat up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse
Levonorgestrel (Plan B- 2 steps) 0.75mg tablet stat and after 12 hours

Ethinyl estradiol 100 μg + Levonorgestrel 0.5 mg

(Yuzpe method)

 2 tablet stat and 2 tablets after 12 hours

Centchroman (Chhaya or Saheli)

  2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice in 24 hours, and within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal  30 mg within 5 days
Conjugated estrogen 15 mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUDs Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.Not suitable for rape victims

 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
While inserting a chest tube in a patient with a pneumothorax, what are the structures pierced sequentially, from outwards to inwards?
  1. Endothoracic fascia
  2. Parietal pleura
  3. External intercostal muscle
  4. Deep fascia
  5. Serratus anterior muscle
questions.solution:
Immediate management of massive hemothorax would include resuscitation and chest tube placement in 5th intercostal space anterior to midaxillary line in the triangle of safety.

Structures pierced sequentially by chest tube:  

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Deep fascia
  4. Serratus anterior muscle
  5. External intercostal muscle
  6. Internal intercostal muscle
  7. Innermost intercostal muscle
  8. Endothoracic fascia
  9. Parietal pleura

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

 Triangle of safety: It is a safe site through which a chest tube can be inserted. It lies:

  • anterior to the midaxillary line
  • above the level of the nipple
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

questions.text:
The given waveform is reflective of pressure changes in the atria transmitted to the great veins. Identify the incorrect statements about it.
  1. Wave 1 is due to atrial contraction
  2. Wave 2 is due to ventricular contraction when the tricuspid valve bulges 
  3. Wave 3 is due to venous filling at the end of ventricular contraction
  4. Wave 4 is due to the fall in atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opens 
  5. Wave 5 is due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole
questions.solution:
Statements IV and V are incorrect. The waveform in the image is the jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveform or the atrial pressure curve, which is reflective of pressure changes in the atria.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave (wave 1 in the image) corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins. It occurs just after the ECG P wave, and just before the first heart sound (S1). Clinical significance:
    • Prominent waves are seen in reduced right ventricular compliance. 
    • Cannon a waves are seen in heart block, right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve
    • Absent 'a' wave in atrial fibrillation
  • c wave (wave 2 in the image) occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • The first part of x descent following the “a” wave in the JVP is due to atrial relaxation during ventricular systole due to atrial relaxation in atrial diastole. The second part of the x descent (x’- marked as wave 3 in the graph) occurring after the “c” wave is due to the final phase of right ventricular contraction which allows the right atrium to expand and allows venous filling.
    • Prominent 'x' descent seen in cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis
  • v wave (wave 4 in the image) is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure. Clinical significance:
    • Prominent 'v' wave in tricuspid regurgitation.
  • y descent (wave 5 in the image) occurs due to the fall in right atrial pressure after the opening of the tricuspid valve. 
    • Rapid 'y' descent in tricuspid regurgitation
    • Absent/prolonged 'y' descent in tricuspid stenosis



Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has high BMI. She tries to lose weight by intermittent fasting. She has fasted for the past 12 hours and is now feeling very hungry. Which of the following is true about the levels of appetite regulating hormones at this stage?

choices.text: High levels of leptin that continue increasing

questions.solution:
This patient will have high levels of ghrelin at this given stage.

Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the stomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before the beginning of food intake or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding.

Other options:

Option A- Neuropeptide Y stimulates appetite, hence this patient, who is now very hungry, will have high levels of NPY at this time.

Option B- Leptin levels are high in patients with obesity. This can decrease by 60 to 70% by 48 hours of fasting. So, it will not be increasing

Option C- Cholecystokinin is a short-acting hormone that is released in response to feeding. It inhibits appetite and decreases food intake to prevent overeating. Its levels are low during fasting and rise immediately after food intake.

Related Pearl: Neurotransmitters and Hormones that influence Feeding and Satiety Centers in the Hypothalamus

questions.text:
A 6-day-old girl is brought by her parents with complaints of increased irritability, poor feeding, and three episodes of seizures. A lumbar puncture is performed and the findings are listed below. Which of the following is a suitable empirical treatment option?

Appearance: Turbid
Opening pressure: 30 cm H2O
WBC count: 1000 cells/µL (90% PMNL)
Glucose level: 35 mg/dL
Protein level:  80 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal meningitis. E. coli > Streptococcus agalactiae are the most likely causative organism of neonatal meningitis. Ampicillin + 3rd-generation cephalosporin is a suitable empirical treatment option as the age of the baby is less than a month.

Neonatal meningitis is classified as either early or late-onset. Early-onset meningitis within the first 72 hours of life. Late-onset meningitis is seen in premature infants and is generally caused by Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella. 

Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity. This makes them prone to meningitis and sepsis. Thus, an infant with a fever who is 28 days or younger, should be evaluated for sepsis. This is done by obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), differential blood count, blood culture, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture. 

Meningococcal infections are usually asymptomatic. If invasive disease occurs, then the clinical spectrum varies widely from meningococcal meningitis (highest proportion) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. It is predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. It is predominantly meningitic form.

Related Pearl: Acute bacterial meningitis - causes and empirical treatment

questions.text: A 10-year old girl presented with complaints of an itchy scalp for a week. On examination of the scalp, there were multiple excoriations along with small, oval-shaped nits on the hair shafts near the scalp and small insects as seen in the image below. Which of the following is an agent that can be prescribed to this patient and offers nearly 100% ovicidal action with a single administration?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pediculosis capitis. Abametapir 0.74% is a drug that gives nearly 100% ovicidal activity with a single administration.

Abametapir is a metalloproteinase inhibitor that has been recently approved for use in pediculosis capitis. Metalloproteinases are essential for the louse development and hatching process. This drug can eliminate both adult lice and eggs with a single topical administration to dry hair for 10 minutes. It offers almost 100% ovicidal activity. It is safe for use in patients older than 3 years. The most common side effect was the development of a rash.

Lice are obligate ectoparasites that infect birds and mammals. Lice found to be infesting humans are of three types:

  • Head louse - Pediculosis capitis
  • Body louse - Pediculosis corporis
  • Pubic/Crab louse - Phthrirus pubis

It is found that the head louse commonly affects young girls more frequently. They can be spread by direct or indirect contact. 

Clinical features include:

  • Scalp pruritus along with erythema and edema
  • Secondary bacterial infestation can occur due to scratching, and it can be associated with scalp impetigo.
  • Pruritic papular lesions on the scalp, nape of the neck
  • Associated with non-specific pruritic eruption due to immune-mediated hypersensitivity reaction
  • Plica polonica is an obsolete term that is used to describe the matting of hair produced by pus and exudate seen in severe neglected cases.

Active infestation is confirmed by the detection of adult lice and nymphs while presence of eggs and egg casts is suggestive of an infection - active or in the past. Most reliable method for active detection is by combing. Treatment and exclusion from school is required only if there is an active infestation.

Treatment involves:

  • General guidelines:
    • Removal of nits
    • All individuals of the household are treated at the same time.
    • All materials that touched the heads of infected persons must be thoroughly washed under hot water.
  • Physical treatment using wet combing
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • First line: Permethrin 1%, Malathion 0.5%
    • Second line: Wet combing, Dimethicone 4%
    • Third line: Ivermectin
    • Novel drug: Abametapir

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here, the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (antral sign/Holman-Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions. Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Given below is a CT image showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with an erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tumor when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

questions.text:
Match the enzyme with the disease caused by its deficiency.
           Enzyme          Disease
 1. Glucose-6-phosphatase a. Cori's disease
 2. Muscle phosphofructokinase b. McArdle's disease 
 3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase c. von Gierke disease
 4. Glycogen debranching enzyme d. Tarui's disease
questions.solution:
Enzyme          Disease
1. Glucose-6-phosphatase

c. von Gierke disease
2. Muscle phosphofructokinase

d. Tarui's 
3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

b. McArdle disease 
4. Glycogen debranching enzyme

a. Cori's disease

Von Gierke disease (Type Ia glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. Laboratory findings include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria.

McArdle disease (Type V glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency. It appears in late childhood or the second decade of life. The typical manifestations are muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency is seen in Cori's disease (type III glycogen storage disorder). Failure to debranch glycogen into glucose subunits results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains which resemble limit dextrin. These children present with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy.

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

Same as Von Gierke's disease

(Acid maltase)

Death by age ~ 2 years (infantile variant)

(Limit dextrinosis)

Generally benign
