questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic pancreatitis was referred to a surgeon who plans to perform the following procedure on him. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition. It consists of distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Chronic pancreatitis is associated with multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

The etiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The diagnosis can be made using Rosemont criteria. It is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. It is explained in the pearl attached below. 

Treatment:

Resection or hybrid surgical procedures as attached in the pearl below. 

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

Related Pearl: Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis

  Parenchymal features Ductal features
Major criteria Major A criteria:
  • Hyperechoic foci with post-acoustic shadowing
Major B criteria:
  • Honeycombing lobularity
 Major A criteria:
  • Main pancreatic duct calculi
Minor criteria
  • Hyperechoic, non-shadowing foci ≥3 mm in length and width
  • Lobularity including three or more noncontiguous lobules in the body or tail
  • Pancreatic cysts ≥2 mm in short axis
  • At least three strands*

   *Strands are defined as hyperechoic lines ≥3 mm in length seen in at least two different directions in the body or tail of the pancreas.
  • Irregular main pancreatic duct (MPD) contour
  • Dilated side branches+
  • Main pancreatic duct dilation (≥3.5 mm in the body or ≥1.5 mm in the tail)
  • Hyperechoic MPD margin >50% of the main pancreatic duct in the body and tail.

 +≥3 tubular anechoic structures, each one ≥1 mm in width, budding from MPD
  Diagnosis of Chronic Pancreatitis:
  • Consistent with chronic pancreatitis
    • 1 major A criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • 1 major A criterion + major B criterion
    • 2 major A criteria
  • Suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 1 major A criterion + <3 minor criteria
    • 1 major B criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • ≥5 minor criteria
  • Indeterminate for chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 3-4 minor criteria in the absence of major criteria
    • Major B criterion + <3 minor criteria
  •  Normal
    • <3 minor criteria

questions.text: Precordial auscultation of a cyanotic newborn revealed a holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left parasternal area. On probing, it is found that the mother had had an episode of unusual behavior two years ago. She had an irritable mood and often spoke fast with pressured speech. She would stay up all night working on bizarre ideas but never feel fatigued. She had been started on medications which she continued to take through her pregnancy fearing a relapse but doesn't know the name of the tablet. Which of the following findings will be found on the chest X-ray of this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of cyanotic congenital heart disease with an antenatal history suggesting lithium intake for mania suggests Ebstein's anomaly. The characteristic finding is that of a box-shaped heart on chest x-ray.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, atrialized right ventricular segment due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets. The tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic causing tricuspid regurgitation. This regurgitation leads to the enlargement of the right atrium producing the characteristic box-shaped heart.

On auscultation, the S1 is widely split due to delayed closure of the anomalous tricuspid valve. The second heart sound is usually normal but may be widely split if there is a right bundle branch block. The tricuspid regurgitation results in the characteristic holosystolic murmur that is heard maximally at the left lower parasternal area. It may sometimes be heard at the apex due to the displaced location of the valve.

Additionally, the right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow resulting in functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) presenting with cyanosis at birth.

A snowman appearance is seen in older children with total anomalous pulmonary venous return. The anomalous pulmonary vein joining the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

An egg-on-side appearance is seen in the transposition of great arteries due to mild cardiomegaly and narrow mediastinum.

A boot-shaped heart (also called Coeur en sabot) is seen in Tetrology of Fallot (TOF). Here, there is right ventricular hypertrophy which causes an uplifted rounded apical shadow facing the left chest wall.

Other options:

Option A: Snowman appearance is seen in older children with total anomalous pulmonary venous return. The anomalous pulmonary vein joining the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

Option B: Egg on side appearance is seen in the transposition of great arteries due to mild cardiomegaly and narrow mediastinum.

Option C: Boot-shaped heart (also called Coeur en sabot) is seen in Tetrology of Fallot (TOF). In TOF, there is right ventricular hypertrophy which causes an uplifted rounded apical shadow facing the left chest wall.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A patient develops a sore throat after general anaesthesia. He was diagnosed as having a postoperative sore throat (POST). The anaesthetist injects a local anaesthetic in the plane of the marked structure. Which of the following pierces the marked structure?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels

questions.solution:
The marked structure shows the thyrohyoid membrane. It is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve, along with superior laryngeal vessels. USG-guided block of the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is used in the management of POST. 

The diagram given below shows the structures piercing the thyrohyoid membrane.

The thyrohyoid membrane is a fibroblastic layer connecting the superior border of the thyroid cartilage to the superior border of the body and the greater cornu of the hyoid.

It facilitates the ascent of the larynx during swallowing.

It is pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and the internal laryngeal nerve. It, therefore, serves as the potential target for ultrasound-guided local anaesthetic injection if an internal laryngeal block is needed to alleviate POST.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a 12-year old boy who died yesterday, after he presented with hydrophobia, abnormal behaviour and insomnia 4 days ago. He was bitten by a stray dog on his leg 2 months ago. Which of the following is not a characteristic of the inclusion bodies shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Virus can be detected within these inclusion  bodies by ultrastructural methods
Typically seen in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus
Virus can be detected within these inclusion  bodies by immunohistochemical methods
These inclusion bodies are seen in all cases

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and hallucinations a few weeks after a dog bite are suggestive of rabies. The image shows Negri bodies which are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies. It is important to appreciate that though Negri bodies are pathognomonic, they are present in only some cases of rabies, not in all cases. i.e, they are highly specific for rabies, but not sensitive.

Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral encephalitis transmitted to humans by the bite of a rabid animal, usually a dog or various wild mammals that are natural reservoirs. Exposure to certain species of bats, even without a known bite, can also lead to rabies. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is virtually 100% fatal. Mostly, domestic dogs are responsible for rabies virus transmission to humans

Spread of rabies can be:

  • Centripetal:
    • The virus enters the peripheral neurons, it moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 mm/day
    • Once within CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes.
  • Centrifugal: 
    • After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and autonomic nerves to: 
      • salivary glands 
      • adrenal glands
      • skin 

Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid animals that serve as vectors.

External examination of the brain shows intense edema and vascular congestion. Neuronal dysfunction associated with an inflammatory reaction is seen that is most severe in the brainstem involving the basal ganglia, spinal cord, and dorsal root ganglia.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in sites usually devoid of inflammation. Though they may not be present always, their presence is pathognomic. The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by both ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods. 

 

Babes nodules are mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in the leptomeninges, including microglial nodules seen in rabies.

The disease begins with nonspecific symptoms such as malaise, headache, and fever. Local paresthesia around the wound is indicative of rabies. CNS excitability with disease progression includes:

  • Painful touch
  • Violent motor responses
  • Convulsions
  • Hydrophobia: Contracture of the pharyngeal musculature on swallowing produces foaming at the mouth, which may create an aversion to swallowing water.
  • Aerophobia: A similar response to hydrophobia occurs when air is stimulated.
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Flaccid paralysis
  • Alternating periods of mania and stupor
  • Coma and death due to respiratory failure.

Clinical stages of rabies:

PHASE TYPICAL DURATION SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS
Incubation period 20-90 Days None
Prodrome 2-10 days Fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, paresthesia
Acute neurologic disease    
Encephalitic/Furious rabies (80%) 2-7 days Anxiety, Agitation, Hyperactivity, hallucinations, hydrophobia, autonomic dysfunction
Paralytic /dumb rabies (20%) 2-10 days Flaccid paralysis in limbs progressing to quadriparesis with facial paralysis.
Coma, death 0-14 days  (14 Days of encephalitic rabies and 30 days of paralytic rabies)

 Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods:

  • Antigen detection - Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of
    • Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test.
    • Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic yield.
  • Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and saliva
  • Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF
  • Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR 
  • Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies

Post-exposure, measures like washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes, irrigation of the wound with alcohol or povidone-iodine, local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

  • Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.
    • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each.
    • Zagreb regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, followed by 1 dose days 7 and 21 each.
  • Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant fell from the stairs while trying to walk. The parents noticed a swelling in the right thigh and brought the child to the casualty ward. A radiograph revealed a mid-shaft femur fracture. Traction was applied as shown. Identify the skin traction.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is that of Gallows traction.

Gallows traction is used in fracture shaft of femur in children less than 2 years of age. Here skin traction is applied to both legs which are then suspended from a frame, providing just enough traction to keep the buttocks of the child just off the bed.

Other options:

Option B: Russell’s traction or Thomas splint is used to treat fractured femur. After 2–4 weeks, when the fracture has sufficiently progressed, it is replaced by hip spica.

Option C: Perkins' traction is used to treat fractures of the shaft femur in adults. Where a pin is inserted at 3 cm distal to the tibial tuberosity and traction is applied using one Bohler stirrup or two Thomas pin mounts.

Option D: Smith’s traction is used in the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Related Pearl: Some Important Traction and Their Uses

1) Gallow/Bryant traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in children below 2 years

2) Perkin traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in adults

3) Russell’s traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Trochanteric fractures

4) Dunlop/Smith traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Supracondylar fracture humerus

5) Buck's traction: 

  • Most common lower limb traction
  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Femoral fractures, acetabular and hip fractures

6)Crutchfield traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

7) Head halter traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

8) Halo-pelvic traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Scoliosis

questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerve is most commonly damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows that the femoral head of the left hip is displaced upwards and laterally, and the affected limb is in adduction. Also, the lesser trochanter is obscured. These features indicate posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. The nerve the most commonly injured in this type of dislocation is the sciatic nerve.

Posterior hip dislocation occurs when the knee of the passenger strikes the dashboard. The affected leg is shortened, and lies in an adducted, internally rotated and slightly flexed position.

Imaging shows the following features:

  • Upward dislocation of the femoral head
  • The size of the femoral head appears smaller compared to the unaffected side
  • Adduction of the affected limb.
  • The lesser trochanter may not be visible due to the internal rotation of the affected leg

Treatment- A pure hip dislocation should be reduced as early as possible to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis. Important maneuvers to reduce posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Rochester method
  • East Baltimore lift
  • Allis
  • Bigelow
  • Stimson

Complications of posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Injury to the superior gluteal artery
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Secondary osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Recurrent instability of the reduced dislocation

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the Trochlear nerve. It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
  • Only cranial nerve with Dorsal exit
  • emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course
  • Only nerve with internal decussation
  • Innervates superior oblique muscle

questions.text: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of pain on defecation, constipation, and tenesmus. He is bothered by frequent staining of undergarments with mucopurulent discharge. He mentions being in a homosexual relationship and has had unprotected sexual intercourse about a week ago. Gram-staining of the mucopurulent discharge is performed and obtained result is depicted in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent for his condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts microscopic findings of gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear from the mucopurulent discharge. The patient complains of mucopurulent discharge, pain on defecation, constipation, and tenesmus after one week of intercourse. As he mentions being in a homosexual relationship, the possibility of anoreceptive intercourse is considered. This clinical scenario along with the image indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Proctitis is a presentation of gonorrheal infection in patients who practice anoreceptive intercourse. It is a common manifestation in homosexual male partners. Women may also develop proctitis due to autoinoculation from cervical discharge or anoreceptive intercourse. The symptoms include mucopurulent discharge, pain on defecation, constipation, and tenesmus. The disruption of anorectal epithelial integrity, together with the local recruitment of HIV-target cell types (dendritic cells and CCR5/CD4+ T cells) predisposes the patient to a higher risk of developing HIV infection.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It uses pilli in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces to reach the subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days.

The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

In males :

  • Acute urethritis: This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Genital discharge: It is mucopurulent that can be described as that resembling 'flow of seed' (semen).
  • Strictures: Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • Water-can perineum: The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses.

In females:

About half the female patients remain asymptomatic. The patients typically present with urethritis, cervical discharge, pruritus, dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

The ectocervix and vagina are not usually affected in adults as the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci. The acidic pH of vaginal secretions is also protective. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium.

The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with abnormal liver function tests.

Lab diagnosis:

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Treatment

According to CDC guidelines (2021), treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections is as follows:

  • Weight <150 kg – Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) in a single dose
  • Weight ≥150 kg – Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) in a single dose

The doses of ceftriaxone are higher than the previous guidelines as the gonococcal minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) are rising worldwide. BASHH (British Association for Sexual Health and HIV) in the United Kingdom also recommends higher doses of ceftriaxone of about 500 mg or 1g along with azithromycin because it would result in fewer failures.

Concurrent chlamydial infection must also be treated unless it has been excluded by molecular testing. First-line drugs used are as follows:

  • Oral azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days (non-pregnant patients only)

The third-generation cephalosporins are contraindicated in patients with a history of IgE-mediated penicillin allergy. The treatment includes:

  • Gemifloxacin 320mg oral + Azithromycin 2g oral
  • Gentamicin 240mg (IM)+ Azithromycin 2g oral

The sexual partners of the patient must be treated to reduce the risk of recurrence. Expedited partner therapy refers to the index patient delivering therapy to one's own partners. However, this type of empirical therapy ignores the importance of direct counseling.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text:
Which of the following scenarios would be considered as criminal negligence by a doctor?
  1. Operating on the wrong limb
  2. Failure to attend to the patient on time
  3. Failure to provide a substitute in his/her absence
  4. Mismanagement of delivery under influence of alcohol
  5. Failure to order an x-ray even when clearly indicated
questions.solution:
The scenarios that would be considered criminal negligence by the doctor include:

  • Operating on the wrong limb
  • Mismanagement of delivery under influence of alcohol

Failure to attend to the patient on time, failure to provide a substitute in his/her absence, and failure to order an x-ray even when clearly indicated contribute to civil negligence.

Professional negligence is defined as the absence of reasonable care and skill, or wilful negligence of a medical practitioner in the treatment of a patient, which causes bodily injury or death to the patient. It is of 4 types:

  1. Civil negligence
  2. Criminal negligence
  3. Corporate negligence
  4. Contributory negligence
Feature Civil negligence Criminal negligence
Offense No violation of law Violation of a criminal law
Type of negligence A simple absence of care and skill Gross inattention and lack of competency
Consent for act Good defense Not a good defense, can be prosecuted
Evidence Strong evidence is sufficient Guilt should be proved beyond reasonable doubt
Litigation Between 2 parties Between state and doctor
Punishment Liable to pay damages Imprisonment with or without fine

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text:
Leukoreduction prevents the transmission of which of the following diseases?
  1. Hepatitis B
  2. HTLV - 1
  3. CMV
  4. HIV 1
  5. Hepatitis D
questions.solution:
Leukoreduction before blood transfusion prevents the transmission of the CMV virus and the HTLV-1 virus.

Leukoreduction refers to the removal of leukocytes from the blood or blood components before blood transfusion.

It prevents the occurrence of certain transfusion reactions such as:

  • Febrile non-hemolytic Transfusion Reactions
  • HLA alloimmunization and platelet refractoriness
  • Prevention of leukocyte-transmitted diseases such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV)-I, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

CMV Virus and the HTLV-1 virus are transmitted by the infected passenger leukocytes found in transfused PRBCs or platelet components. Hence, Leukoreduction helps prevent them.

Leukoreduction does not prevent other infections, such as HIV-1 and the Hepatitis group of viruses.

Vaccine

1. Pneumococcal conjugate  A.Oral
2. BCG  B.Subcutaneous
3. JE C.Intradermal
4. Rotavirus D.Intramuscular
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

BCG is intradermally administered.

Hepatitis B vaccine, Pentavalent vaccine, along with DPT, Pneumococcal conjugate Vaccine, and the tetanus toxoid are administered via the intramuscular route. 

OPV and Rotaviral vaccines are administered orally.

The vaccines that are administered subcutaneously are Measles/Rubella vaccine and the JE vaccine.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with headaches and palpitations for the past 3 hours. She had a history of seizures in the past. Her serum and urine are positive for metanephrines. Any of the following may be associated with her underlying condition except:
questions.solution:
In this child presenting with headache, palpitations, and a positive urinary metanephrine test, the probable diagnosis is pheochromocytoma. It can be associated with plexiform neurofibroma (NF 1), Cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas (VHL syndrome) or Carotid body tumour/ glomus tumor  (Familial Paraganglioma  Syndrome). However, Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2), which is not typically seen in association with pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2), familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF 1).

Pheochromocytoma has a variable presentation and is called 'the great masquerader’. This is because of the variability in the catecholamine secreted by different types of pheochromocytoma.

It may present as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating, along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Precipitants of pheochromocytoma include:

  • Surgery
  • Pregnancy
  • Exercise, stress or trauma
  • Medications such as steroids, metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

The cut section of pheochromocytoma is greyish-pink with areas of haemorrhage and necrosis. Histologically, there is a classical Zellballen pattern with nests of neuroendocrine chief cells and peripheral glia-like sustentacular cells. The chief cells are positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin, while the sustentacular cells are positive for S100.

The image below shows tumour cells:

  • (a) with a distinct ‘‘pepper and salt’’ chromatin of the nucleolus and “Zellballen” or nesting pattern
  • (b) Strong chromogranin-stained pattern
  • (c) Synaptophysin intermediately stained pattern
  • (d) Ki-67 poorly stained pattern

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines are some of the most sensitive and specific tests for the detection of pheochromocytoma.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localising the tumour since the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET uses radioactive tracers to identify the primary tumour as well as the extra-adrenal tumours and metastases.

The image given below shows a coronal section of the abdomen with a left-sided pheochromocytoma over the left kidney.

The image given below shows a left-sided pheochromocytoma, as seen from MIBG Scintigraphy. The thyroid and bladder are also seen due to the normal physiologic uptake.

Treatment of pheochromocytoma includes:

  • Phenoxybenzamine is the drug of choice which causes irreversible and non-selective alpha-1 receptor blockade, but it needs to be stopped 48 hours preoperatively
  • Other alpha-blockers like selective alpha-1 receptor antagonists, namely, Prazosin and Doxazosin, are also used for the management of hypertension.
  • Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction.
  • Surgical resection of the tumour is the definitive treatment. Postoperative hypovolemia, hypotension and hypoglycemia are commonly seen.
  • Malignant pheochromocytoma requires surgical resection and Averbuch's chemotherapy regimen with the use of Mitotane as an adjuvant or for palliation.
  • Lifelong yearly follow-up should be done postoperatively.

Other options:

Option B: Plexiform neurofibroma is a characteristic finding of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF 1), along with cafe au lait macules, Lisch nodules, pheochromocytoma, axillary and inguinal freckling.

Option C: Cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas are associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome along with pheochromocytoma, bilateral kidney tumours and pancreatic tumours. 

Option D: Carotid body glomus tumour and extra-adrenal paraganglioma are characteristic of familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman is on an anti-arrhythmic drug after she had ventricular fibrillation 3 months back. During her routine diabetic workup, the ophthalmological examination shows corneal findings as in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the drug implicated in this condition?

choices.text: It is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease
It belongs to the same class of drugs as propafenone
The most common cutaneous side effect is photosensitivity

questions.solution:
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of golden-brown lines, as shown in the above image, is called vortex keratopathy (corneal verticillata). Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of amiodarone. Amiodarone is a Class III anti-arrhythmic drug whereas propafenone is a class IC antiarrhythmic.

Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through various mechanisms:

  • Blockade of the transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents mainly
  • Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery
  • Decreases Ca2+ current
  • Inhibition of cell-to-cell coupling, thus decreasing conduction velocity

Ventricular tachycardia and recurrent ventricular fibrillation are the most important indications for amiodarone. It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation when other drugs have failed.

Amiodarone is known to cause multiple side effects. Photosensitivity in the form of blue-grey discoloration occurs in body areas that are exposed to the sun, as shown in the image below. The most serious side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can progress rapidly and be fatal. Hypo- and hyperthyroidism can also occur during chronic amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone is a blocker of CYP3A4 and CYP2C9, and thus, dose modifications of concurrent drugs may be required.

 

Other causes of vortex keratopathy include:

  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine
  • Fabry disease

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

Other options:

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

Option C: Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with fever & pain in her left breast, which appears as below. On examination of the affected side, there is local warmth,  point tenderness over the dependent area, and a positive fluctuation test. There is no palpable lump or skin thinning. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side. The contralateral breast is normal. What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and Drainage after confirming with an ultrasound
Broad spectrum antibiotics only  after confirming with an ultrasound
Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics - Repeated aspiration if necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscess.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding obesity?

choices.text: Naltrexone and Bupropion combination for obesity is banned by the FDA
Canagliflozin is used in obese diabetic patients
Laron syndrome patients have peripheral obesity
Surgery for obesity is indicated in patients with BMI more than 35

questions.solution:
Canagliflozin causes moderate weight loss and is used in diabetic patients who are obese.

It is a Sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, having an insulin-independent mechanism that offers a considerable advantage of increasing urinary glucose excretion without inducing hypoglycemia and promoting weight loss due to loss of 300 to 400kcal/day.

Drugs used in obesity treatment:

  • Orlistat: Acts in the gastrointestinal system inhibiting intestinal lipase and hence reducing fat absorption.
  • Lorcaserin: Selective serotonin receptor agonist
  • Combination of Phentermine hydrochloride and Topiramate
  • Combination of Naltrexone and Bupropion Hydrochloride
  • Liraglutide: Injectable Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist

Option A: Naltrexone and Bupropion combination has been approved by FDA for the treatment of obesity.

Option C: Laron syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is mainly caused by mutations in the gene that encodes the GH receptor, resulting in GH resistance. This causes a severe deficiency in serum insulin-like growth factor – 1 (IGF- 1 ), resulting in short stature (dwarfism). Affected individuals have a prominent forehead, depressed nasal bridge, small mandible, and central obesity.

They may have recurrent hypoglycemic seizures. Partial resistance to GH may cause some cases of idiopathic short stature without features of Laron syndrome.

Option D: Surgery for obesity is indicated in patients with BMI more than 40 or BMI more than 35 with associated co-morbidities.

Obesity also causes variable degrees of GH deficiency and male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism that are typically reversible with sufficient weight loss.

Related Pearl: Anti-obesity drugs

Centrally acting anti-obesity drugs: The biologic effect of these agents on appetite regulation is produced by augmentation of the neurotransmission of three monoamines, norepinephrine, serotonin (5-HT) and dopamine.

  • Phentermine – Sympathomimetic (Phentermine is usually used in combination with topiramate)
  • Lorcaserin – Selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist

Peripherally acting medications:

  • Orlistat is a synthetic hydrogenated derivative of a naturally occurring lipase inhibitor, lipostatin, that is produced by the mold Streptomyces toxytricini.

Anti-obesity drugs in development:

  • Bupropion: Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Naltrexone: Opioid receptor antagonist

Liraglutide: Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist

Note: Tirzepatide is a GIP and GLP-1 agonist recently approved for weight loss treatment.

questions.text: A child with delayed developmental milestones, lethargy and megaloblastic anemia which does not respond to treatment with iron, folic acid ,vitamin B12 or pyridoxine, with elevated level of orotic acid in urine.  Which among the following will alleviate the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Uridine is a pyrimidine nucleoside that can be useful in treating orotic aciduria as it bypasses the missing activity in the pathway and can be converted to other pyrimidines.

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. This enzyme contains two activities, orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidine decarboxylase. The lack of pyrimidines impairs nucleic acid synthesis needed for hematopoiesis, explaining the megaloblastic anemia in this infant. Orotic acid accumulates and spills into the urine, resulting in orotic acid crystals and orotic acid urinary obstruction. The presence of orotic acid in urine might suggest that the defect could be ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, but the lack of hyperammonemia rules out a defect in the urea cycle.

Adenine, Guanine and hypoxanthine are purines.

questions.text: The ABG value of a patient presenting with vomiting is likely to correspond to which of the following areas in the given acid-base nomogram?
questions.solution:
The image shows the acid-base nomogram, which is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH. The area marked 'C' is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis, which is seen in vomiting.

In the area marked 'C', pH is above the normal limits (7.35–7.45) and thus implies the presence of alkalosis. Plasma HCO3-  is higher than the normal limits (22–28 mEq/L). This implies that the alkalosis is due to an increase in the plasma HCO3- and is thus metabolic in origin. 

Net gain of [HCO3-] or loss of nonvolatile acid (usually HCl by vomiting) from the extracellular fluid causes metabolic alkalosis. HCO3− secretion in the small bowel cannot begin when vomiting results in the loss of HCl from the stomach; as a result, HCO3− is retained in the extracellular fluid.

Compensatory responses for primary metabolic disorders move the PaCO2 in the same direction as the change in HCO3−. Electrolyte abnormalities seen are hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Clinical features include:

  • Mental confusion
  • Reduced level of alertness 
  • Predisposition to: seizures, paresthesia, muscular cramping, tetany, arrhythmias, and hypoxemia in COPD

Management of metabolic alkalosis involves:

  • Correction of the underlying cause
  • Remove factors causing an increase in HCO3- absorption like extracellular fluid volume contraction or hypokalemia.
  • In case of excess fluid administration, renal loss can be encouraged by the administration of acetazolamide.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis:

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss:
    • Removal of gastric secretions, such as in vomiting or gastric aspiration
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
  • Renal loss:
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells:
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome
 

Other options:

Option A: (Area B- corresponds to chronic respiratory acidosis) An increase in PaCO2 and a decrease in pH indicates respiratory acidosis, which occurs due to severe pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle exhaustion, or anomalies in ventilatory control. Renal adaptation raises the [HCO3-] in chronic respiratory acidosis (>24 h) by 4 mmol/L for each 10-mmHg increase in PaCO2. It is seen in conditions like emphysema, pneumoconiosis and bronchitis. 

Option C: (Area F- corresponds to metabolic acidosis). Increased endogenous acid production (such as lactate and ketoacids), loss of bicarbonate (as in diarrhoea), or accumulation of endogenous acids due to low excretion of net acid by the kidney (chronic kidney disease) can all lead to metabolic acidosis.

Option D: (Area E- corresponds to chronic respiratory alkalosis). Respiratory alkalosis is induced by a process involving hyperventilation resulting in a decrease in PaCO2 and an increase in HCO3−/ PaCO2 ratio, thus increasing the pH. Causes include anxiety-hyperventilation, fear, hypoxic stimulation and pulmonary causes such as pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax and COPD exacerbations. Chronic respiratory alkalosis occurs when hypocapnia persists for >3–5 days. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: A child was brought to you with complaints of distal muscle weakness. Further evaluation reveals the presence of the following type of cataract in this child. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a Christmas tree cataract is suggestive of Myotonic dystrophy, which usually shows CTG (trinucleotide) repeat mutation.

Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions:

  • GAA- Friedreich ataxia
  • CAG- Huntington disease, Spinocerebellar ataxia
  • CGG- Fragile X syndrome.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a pathological cause for neonatal jaundice is least likely?

choices.text: 4 week old neonate with total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
2 week old neonate presenting with yellowing of arms and thighs
1 week old neonate presenting with yellowing of palms and soles
12 hour old neonate with elevated direct bilirubin levels

questions.solution:
Jaundice presenting between days 1-21 suggests physiologic jaundice. So, among the given options, 2-week old neonate presenting with yellowing of arms and thighs is least likely to have a pathological cause of jaundice.

Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth
  • Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant
  • Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level
  • Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in the palms and soles (≈ 20 mg/dL)
  • Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
  • Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with mild fever, myalgia, and fatigue for the last 10 days. He had non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Blood investigations revealed mild lymphocytosis and elevated ESR. Histological examination of the lymph node showed follicular hyperplasia and irregular clusters of tissue macrophages with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The suspected etiological organism's life-cycle is depicted below. All of the following are true except:

choices.text: Acute congenital presentation may manifest as fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly and petechial rash
Most infections in adults who are immunocompetent are usually asymptomatic
Sabin Feldman dye test detects IgM antibodies against the etiological organism
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used as  treatment in immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii. It is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is used in the diagnosis which is a serological test done for the detection of IgG (not IgM) antibodies against toxoplasma.

Acute congenital toxoplasmosis may manifest as fever, jaundice, petechial rashes, microphthalmia, cataract, glaucoma, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, myocarditis, cerebral calcifications, and chorioretinitis.

Most infections in adults who are immunocompetent are usually asymptomatic. Active progression of infection is more likely in immunocompromised individuals. Immunologically competent adults with just lymphadenopathy do not require specific therapy.Pyremethamine & Silfadiazine is the drug of choice for treatment in immunocompetent and immunocompramised patients. Trimemoprim-sulfamethoxazole is also used for the treatment of immunocompromised patients. Alternative regimen for those that cannot tolerate this is with dapsone & pyrimethamine.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of anti neutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitides?
  1. Microscopic polyangiitis
  2. Polyarteritis nodosa
  3. Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  4. Henoch-Schonlein vasculitis
  5. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  6. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
questions.solution:
Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) associated vasculitides include:

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Other ANCA-associated diseases are drug-induced vasculitis and renal limited vasculitis.

Small vessel vasculitides are either ANCA-associated vasculitides or immune complex vasculitides.

  • Immune complex vasculitides can be caused by:
    • Infections: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human Immune deficiency virus (HIV), or endocarditis.
    • Autoimmune conditions such as SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, and Sjögren syndrome. 
    • ANCA-associated vasculitides show little or no immune complex deposition and are known as pauci-immune vasculitides.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) involves upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidney. Symptoms of the upper respiratory tract include bloody nasal discharge, nasal ulceration, sinusitis, and chronic otitis media, characteristic saddle nose deformity due to damage to the nasal cartilage. Symptoms of the lower respiratory tract include lung nodules and alveolar hemorrhage. Renal symptoms include high blood pressure, proteinuria, hematuria and a rapidly progressive renal failure. A c-ANCA pattern with positive anti-PR3 antibodies is seen. Lung biopsy will show evidence of vasculitis and necrotizing granuloma formation, which is characteristic of this disease. Granulomas are absent in the kidney biopsy.

Microscopic polyangiitis causes small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis without granuloma formation. Glomerulonephritis and acute renal failure are the common manifestations. Anti-MPO antibodies positivity with a p-ANCA pattern is seen. Kidney biopsy will show vasculitis of the capillaries without granuloma formation and crescentic glomerulonephritis. Lung involvement is less common.

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome) involves the skin, cardiac and gastrointestinal tract and peripheral nervous system with associated eosinophilia. Biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltrates and eosinophilic granulomas.

Drug-induced vasculitis may be seen with drugs such as indomethacin, ATT drugs like rifampicin and isoniazid, and anti-hyperthyroid drugs like propylthiouracil, methimazole, carbimazole

The assessment of disease activity includes assessment of inflammatory markers, ANCA antibodies and renal function tests like urea and electrolytes, urine protein quantification, urine microscopy.

Disease activity can be monitored with tools like Birmingham Vasculitis Activity Score (BVAS).

Treatment involves:

  • Induction of remission to avoid or slow down organ involvement by cyclophosphamide in addition to high-dose steroids.
  • Plasma exchange or intravenous rituximab can be used for the same.
  • Rituximab is superior to cyclophosphamide in disease relapse.
  • Maintenance of remission is usually done by either methotrexate or azathioprine.
 

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome
