Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text:
While taking a sleep history from a patient in the psychiatric OPD, you notice she uses the word "torangle" when referring to her bed. She replies that she sleeps on the floor instead of her bed when you asked if she had any trouble sleeping lately. She is concerned about the details of her bedside table and lighting when she was asked how her sleep routine was. Which of the following thought disorders are seen in her?
  1. Neologism
  2. Perseveration
  3. Clang association
  4. Circumstantiality
  5. Tangentiality
  6. Derailment
questions.solution:
The thought disorders seen in her are neologism - making up a new word like 'torangle', circumstantiality - concerned about the details of the bedside table and lighting when asked about her sleep routine and tangentiality - mentions that she sleeps on the floor and not on the bed when asked if there is any difficulty falling asleep.

Neologism: The patient makes up a new word or condensed combination of several words, that is not a true word and is not readily understandable.

Example:
Doctor: "How are you feeling today?"
Patient: "I am feeling glaberfest"

Circumstantiality: The patient includes irrelevant details and goes on talking in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

Example:
Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"
Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

Tangentiality: The patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

Example:
Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

Neologisms and tangentiality are disorders of form of thought while circumstantiality is a disorder of tempo, under stream of thought.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text:
Match the antibodies seen in systemic lupus erythematosis with their specific clinical utility.
1. Anti-Sm a. Best screening test for SLE
2. Anti-histone b. Predisposes to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block 
3. Anti-nuclear c. Predisposes clotting & thrombocytopenia
4. Anti-phospholipid d. Specific for SLE. Simultaneous RNP positivity is also seen.
5. Anti-Ro e. More frequently associated with drug-induced lupus than SLE
questions.solution:
The correctly matched antibodies seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosis with their clinical relevance are given below.

1. Anti-Sm d. Specific for SLE. Simultaneous RNP positivity is also seen
2. Anti-histone e. More frequently associated with drug-induced lupus than SLE
3. Anti-nuclear a. Best screening test for SLE
4. Anti-phospholipid c. Predisposes clotting & thrombocytopenia
5. Anti-Ro b. Predisposes to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block

Systemic lupus erythromatosis (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that causes cell damage due to autoantibodies and immune complexes. It is more commonly seen in females and is associated with autoimmune activation of innate immunity, autoantibodies, and T-cells. Several factors predispose to this disease including:

  • Genetic factors: HLA-DR3, DNAse-1, STAT4, APOL-1
  • Environmental factors: UV light, smoking, crystalline silica, Ebstein Barr Virus infection

Diagnosis of SLE is based on the characteristic clinical features and autoantibodies.

Systemic Lupus International Collaborating clinic criteria (SLICC) for diagnosis of SLE:

Clinical manifestations:

  1. Skin:
    - Acute/ Subacute: photosensitivity, malar rash, maculopapular lesions
    - Chronic: discoid lupus, panniculitis
  2.  Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Renal:
    - Protein/Creatinine >=0.5
    - RBC casts
    - Biopsy
  5. Synovitis >+2 joints
  6. Serositis - pleurisy, pericarditis
  7. Neurologic:
    - Seizures
    - Psychosis
    - Mononeuritis
    - Myelitis
    - Cranial neuropathies
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia or lymphopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia

Immunologic manifestations:

  1. ANA > reference negative value
  2. Anti-dsDNA > reference
  3. Anti-Sm
  4. Antiphospholipid:
    - lupus anticoagulant
    - anticardiolipin
    - anti-beta glycoprotein I
  5. Low serum complements
  6. Direct Coomb's test positive in the absence of hemolytic anemia

The presence of any 4 criteria with at least 1 in each category is diagnosed as SLE with 93% specificity and 92 % sensitivity. A positive renal biopsy is read as systemic lupus even if none of the other features is present.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Antibody Prevelance % Antigen Recognized Clinical utility
Antinuclear Antibody 98 Multiple nuclear Best screening test; repeated -ve test make SLE unlikely
Anti dS-DNA 70 DNA(double stranded) High titres are SLE specific & in some patients correlates  with disease activity, nephritis & vasculitis
Anti-Sm 25 Protein complexed to 6 species of nuclear U1 RNA Specific for SLE; no definite correlations; most patients also have anti RNP 
More common in black & asians than white
Anti-RNP 40 Protein complexed to U1 RNA Not Specific for SLE; high titre associated with syndromes that have overlap features of several rheumatic syndromes including SLE;
More common in blacks and whites 
Anti-Ro( SS-A) 30 Protein complexed to hY RNA,
Primarily 60kDA and 52kDA		 Not Specific for SLE; associated with sicca syndrome, predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus & to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block; associated with decrease risk of nephritis
Anti-La( SS-B) 10 47kDa protein complexed to hY RNA Usually associated with anti-RO, associated with decreased  risk for nephritis
Antihistone 70 Histones associated with DNA
(In nucleosome & chromatin)		 More frequent in drug induced lupus than in SLE
Antiphospholipid 50 Phospholipid,β2 glycoprotein1(β2 G1) cofactor , prothrombin 3 tests available-ELISAs for cardiolipin & β2 G1,
Sensitive prothrombin time (DRVVT)
Predisposes to clotting, fetal loss, thrombocytopenia
Antierythrocyte 60 Erythrocyte membrane   Measured as direct Coombs test , a small proportion devlop overt hemolysis
Antiplatelet 30 Surface & altered cytoplasmic antigens on platelets Associated with thrombocytopenia, but sensitivity & specificity are not good:
This is not a useful clinical test
Antineuronal
(includes antiglutamate receptor)		 60 Neuronal & lymphocyte surface antigens In some series, a positive test in CSF correlates with active CNS lupus
Antiribosomal P 20 Protein in ribosomes In some series, a positive test serum correlates with depression or psychosis due to CNS lupus

questions.text: You are conducting a meta-analysis of studies on the effects of statin drugs and the risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with cardiomyopathy. The analysis is presented as the following plot. Which among the given statements is incorrect regarding the interpretation of these plots?

choices.text: The diamond shows the overall pooled results
Each rectangle depicts a single study
The vertical dashed line is the “line of no effect"
The size of the rectangle denotes the sample size

questions.solution:
The given plot for the meta-analysis is a forest plot. The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect", signifying no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1)

The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analyzed measure of effect.

Forest plots allow the results to be seen at a glance with the identification of the outliers.

Interpretation of the graph given in the image: 

  • Each rectangle represents a single study. 
    - ex: Smith et al, Jones et al 
  • The size of the rectangle represents the sample size
    - ex: Smith et al 1999 had a small sample size whereas Chu et al 2009 had a large sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side represents the confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
    - ex: Ng et al 2004 has a small confidence interval and is more reliable than Jones et al 1993 as it has longer confidence intervals
  • The vertical solid line- the “line of no effect", no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1) 
    -the location of the result depicts whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not. Any study line which crosses the line of null effect does not illustrate a statistically significant result.
  • A diamond represents the overall pooled result of the meta-analysis where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged. 
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
 

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and declining scholastic performance. An X-ray is done which is shown below. Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids are suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia aperta(Hypernasality) would not be seen in this condition, but rhinolalia clausa(Hyponasality) would be seen instead.

Adenoids also known as nasopharyngeal tonsils are prone to physiological enlargement during childhood. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice). They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining scholastic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, pinched in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth. 

When symptoms are bothersome, it is removed by adenoidectomy. Otherwise, decongestant nasal drops and antihistamines can be used.

Indications for adenoidectomy:

  • Symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, and rhinolalia clausa due to adenoid hypertrophy
  • Recurrent ear discharge
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion secondary to adenoid hyperplasia

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft/ submucous palate: Adenoidectomy leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency in these cases and may cause rhinolalia aperta.
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Active local infection

Given below are the conditions with rhinolalia clausa and rhinolalia aperta:

Rhinolalia clausa
(Hyponasality)		 Rhinolalia aperta
(Hypernasality)
Common cold Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Nasal allergy Congenitally short soft palate
Nasal polypi Submucous palate
Nasal growth Large nasopharynx
Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate
Nasopharyngeal mass Paralysis of the soft palate
Familial speech pattern Post adenoidectomy
Habitual Oronasal fistula
  Familial speech pattern
  Habitual

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding zonula occludens?
  1. They are present in the apical margins of the epithelial cells.
  2. They are made up of units called cadherins which obliterate the space between cells.
  3. They permit the passage of ions and intracellular signalling molecules between adjacent cells.
  4. Integrins and connexons are the transmembrane proteins that form tight junctions.
  5. They prevent the movement of proteins in the plane of the membrane.
questions.solution:
Zonula occludens are present in the apical margins of the epithelial cells and contain 3 transmembrane proteins - occludin, junctional adhesion molecule, and claudins. 

They are also known as tight junctions and characteristically surround the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. Also important to the endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation. They are made up of ridges- half from one cell and a half from another cell- which adhere so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the selective passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signaling molecules in between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Three families of transmembrane proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions:

  1. Occludin
  2. Junctional adhesion molecule
  3. Claudins

 

Other intercellular junctions -

Gap junctions:

  • The gap between the two cells in these types of junctions is about 4nm.
  • These junctions are formed by units called connexons, which are present in the membrane of each cell.
  • Each connexon is made up of six protein subunits called connexins. 
  • They permit substances to pass between the cells, without entering the ECF.
  • The pore diameter is around 0.8 to 1.4  nm, which permits the passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes which weigh up to 1000 Da.
  • They also permit rapid propagation of electrical activity from cell to cell, as well as the exchange of various chemical messengers and intracellular signalling molecules.

Hemidesmosomes:

  • They look like half-desmosomes.
  • They attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments.
  • They contain integrins.

Adherent junctions:

  • Adherent junctions or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens.
  • It contains cadherins.

 

The image below shows adherent junctions.

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is admitted for the treatment of a fractured tibia. On the 3rd day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and becomes agitated. He has visual and tactile hallucinations. On examination, he is disoriented, diaphoretic and has tachycardia and fever. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delirium tremens. Administration of lorazepam would be the appropriate treatment for this patient. 

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal. Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options: 

Option A: Phenytoin which is a non-benzodiazepine anti convulsant is usually not helpful in the prevention or treatment of alcohol withdrawal delirium or seizures. 

Option B: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic and is usually avoided in patients with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal due to its propensity to reduce the seizure threshold in alcoholics.

Option C: Fomepizole is used in the treatment of ethylene glycol and methanol intoxication. 

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

questions.text: During routine USG examination of a G2P1L1 woman, you note findings suggestive of placenta increta. What is the pathology involved in this condition?

choices.text: Villi are attached to lower uterine segment

questions.solution:
In placenta increta, the chorionic villi invade the myometrium.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. These occur due to:

  • Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 
  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

The various types of morbidly adherent placenta are:

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

 

Note: Villi are attached to the lower uterine segment in placenta previa.

 

Investigations that help in diagnosing these conditions:

  • USG
  • Color Doppler 
  • MRI 

 

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

 

The image below shows placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have microcephaly, spasticity, limb contractures, subcortical calcifications in the brain. Congenital Zika syndrome is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for confirming this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
RT-PCR is the investigation of choice for diagnosing congenital Zika syndrome.

Laboratory diagnosis of congenital Zika syndrome included the following -

  • real-time RT-PCR of serum or urine samples - investigation of choice
  • Serum Zika virus IgM antibodies ELISA
  • If IgM is positive, then PRNT (plaque reduction neutralization test) is used to confirm the specificity of IgM antibodies

The samples used for these tests are serum or urine or CSF, which should be collected within the first 2 days of life.

Zikavirus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted primarily by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes genus, mainly the Aedes aegypti. It is also known to be transmitted by - 

  • Materno-fetal or intrauterine transmission
  • Sexual intercourse, due to exchange of body fluids
  • Blood/ blood products transfusion
  • Organ transplantation

The majority of the people infected with this virus are asymptomatic. Few of them develop mild symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, malaise and headache, which usually last for about a week. It has been reported to trigger Guillain-Barre syndrome, myelitis and neuropathy in older children and adults.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy is known to cause severe defects in the fetus and newborn, known as congenital Zika syndrome. The highest risk of birth defects occurs from infection during the first trimester. It can also lead to abortions, preterm births and stillbirths.

Clinical features of congenital Zika virus syndrome -

Head findings:

  • Severe microcephaly (>3 SD below the mean head circumference)
  • Partially collapsed skull
  • Overlapping cranial sutures
  • Prominent occipital bone
  • Redundant scalp skin

CNS findings:

  • Cerebral cortex thinning
  • Increased fluid spaces
  • Abnormal gyral patterns
  • Corpus callosal abnormalities
  • Subcortical calcifications
  • Reduced white matter
  • Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia
  • Neurological impairment
  • Pronounced early hypertonia/ spasticity with extrapyramidal symptoms
  • Seizures

Ocular findings:

  • Macular scarring
  • Focal pigmentary retinal mottling
  • Microphthalmia
  • Coloboma
  • Cataracts
  • Posterior anomalies
  • Optic nerve hypoplasia/ atrophy
  • Chorioretinal atrophy
  • Visual impairment

Other findings-

  • Congenital limb contractures (arthrogryposis multiplex congenita)
  • Unilateral or bilateral club foot
  • Hearing impairment 

 

The image below shows features of microcephaly.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird's beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM). 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.  

The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry. The findings are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. 

The image below shows the bird beak appearance of the esophagus on the barium swallow.

 Management is as follows:

  • Heller's myotomy
  • Partial fundoplication
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is mainly done for type 1 and 2. For type 3, it is done if there is recurrence after surgery. 

    In this procedure, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created; through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided.

    The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 

 Other options:

Option A: NOTES - Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery - It helps access the peritoneal cavity or the abdominal cavity through the gastrointestinal tract, without incising the anterior abdominal wall. It is in the experimental stage and is proposed to replace laparoscopic appendicectomy or cholecystectomy. 

Option B: SILS - Single incision laparoscopic surgery - It is also known as 'scarless’ surgery. It has recently been applied in recent times for gallbladder removal or complex biliopancreatic procedures to minimize the invasiveness of the surgery. 

Option D: ROSE -  Restorative obesity surgery endoscopy helps restore the stomach pouch and size of the outlet in patients who have undergone gastric bypass to help them regain back the weight. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP
Increased duration of peristalsis
Normal peristalsis
DCI>8000mmHg

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following chest radiograph findings according to the respective grades of sarcoidosis, in increasing order.

A. Pulmonary fibrosis

B. Lung parenchymal infiltrates and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

C. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with right paratracheal node involvement

D. Parenchymal infiltrates without lymphadenopathy
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1

 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis

 

The parenchymal infiltrates in sarcoidosis are predominantly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates. However, focal infiltrates, acinar shadows, nodules, and cavitation may also be seen.

Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis that involves: right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign (shown in the image below).

Stages of sarcoidosis are shown in the X-rays below.

questions.text: A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple, hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. 

It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described as follows:

  • Fishy odor
  • Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid
  • Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels.

Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal discharge.

Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with COVID died despite the best possible treatment given as per protocols. The relatives cause grievous hurt to the medical personnel and destroy hospital property. What is the maximum punishment with which the relatives can be charged under the recently passed ordinance of Epidemic diseases act, 2020?

choices.text: 2 years imprisonment and 1 lakh rupees fine
3 years imprisonment and 2 lakh rupees fine
5 years imprisonment and 3 lakh rupees fine
7 years imprisonment and 5 lakh rupees fine

questions.solution:
Under the recently passed ordinance under the Epidemic diseases act,2020, if the healthcare personnel, on duty during an epidemic, suffers grievous hurt, then the offender(s) will be charged with a maximum punishment of 7 years imprisonment with a fine of 5 lakh rupees.

Healthcare personnel covered under the amendment are:

  • Any public and clinical healthcare provider like a doctor, nurse, paramedical worker and community health worker
  • Any other person empowered under the Act to take measures to prevent the outbreak of the disease or spread thereof
  • Any person declared as such by the State Government, by notification in the Official Gazette

Violence against or causing grievous hurt to healthcare personnel on duty during an epidemic, causing damage or loss to any property is a cognizable-nonbailable offence, to be investigated by a police officer with the rank of Inspector or above.

 Offence committed Minimum time of imprisonment with fine Maximum time of imprisonment with fine
Commits/ abets violence against a health care service personnel 3 months, 50 thousand rupees 5 years, 2 lakh rupees
Abets/causes damage or loss to any property 3 months, 50 thousand rupees 5 years, 2 lakh rupees
Causes grievous hurt to a healthcare service personnel 6 months, 1 lakh rupees 7 years, 5 lakh rupees

In case of a complaint of grievous hurt against the healthcare service personnel on duty during an epidemic, the court will presume that the offence has been committed unless proved otherwise.

questions.text: While performing two-point discrimination test in a patient, the normal stimulus is primarily sensed by:
questions.solution:
While performing a two-point discrimination test in a patient, the normal stimulus is primarily sensed by Meissner’s corpuscles.

Two-point discrimination tests the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) system, the central pathway for touch and proprioception. Meissner's corpuscles are encapsulated mechanoreceptors present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips and lips. They have small receptive fields and are rapidly adapting which helps in two­ point discrimination. 

Other mechanoreceptors:

Pacinian corpuscles (Option A) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of nerve endings encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving them an onion-like appearance. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly.

 

Merkel discs (Option C) are seen in the epidermis of glabrous skin. They are slowly adapting receptors and have very small receptive fields. These receptors detect vertical indentations of the skin. They are expanded dendritic endings.

 

Ruffini corpuscles (Option D) are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly adapting receptors. They detect stretch and joint rotation.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs    

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Mechanoreceptor Systems

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with chronic kidney disease was found to have an elevated serum PTH concentration and a low serum concentration of 25-hydroxyvitamin D. He was treated with ergocalciferol. After few months, his kidney disease progressed and required maintenance hemodialysis and his serum PTH concentration became markedly elevated. Which of the following drugs can be used to lower the patient’s serum PTH concentration?
questions.solution:
The patient requires administration of calcitriol, which acts directly on parathyroid to inhibit the PTH production.

In patients with CKD requiring hemodialysis, there is impaired production of active vitamin D due to the reduced activity of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D  to its more active form 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). As a result, there is deficiency of the active form of vitamin D. This causes impaired absorption of calcium from the GIT.

The decreased serum calcium levels trigger the secretion of PTH, which maintains the calcium level through resorption of the bone. Also, these patients have elevated serum phosphate due to renal impairment, which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Administration of the calcitriol acts directly on the parathyroid to inhibit PTH production. Cholecalciferol is not effective in patients with advanced renal disease who cannot form adequate amounts of active vitamin D metabolites.

questions.text: You are a microbiologist examining a water sample brought to you by the municipal corporation. They suspect fecal contamination of the source of drinking water. The sole presence of which of the following organisms indicates that the contamination was not recent?
questions.solution:
The presence of Clostridium perfringens alone, in the absence of the coliform group, in a water sample suggests that the contamination is not recent.

Clostridium perfringens occur in faeces in much smaller numbers than E. coli. The spores of this organism are capable of surviving in water for a longer time than organisms of the coliform group and resist chlorination at the doses normally used to disinfect.

Detection of Clostridium perfringens can be done using varying quantities of the water samples, incubated in a litmus milk medium (anaerobically) at 37°C for five days. The presence of 'stormy clot' formation indicates the presence of Clostridium perfringens.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production.

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test:

Methodology: Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single-strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37 degrees Celsius. These tubes are incubated at 44 degrees Celcius and examined after 24 hours.

Interpretation: 

  1. Tubes exhibiting gas in Durham's tubes are deemed to contain E.Coli.
  2. From the number of positive tubes obtained, the number of E.coli bacteria present in the water sample tested can be estimated by referring to Mc cardy's probability tables.
  3. The presence of E.coli can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilisation.

Classification of the quality of drinking water based on bacteriological tests :

  Presumptive coliform count/100ml E.coli count/100ml
Class I - Excellent 0 0
Class II - Satisfactory 1-3 0
Class III - Suspicious 4-10 0
Class IV - Unsatisfactory >10 0.1 or more

Other options:

Option A: Recent faecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (faecal streptococci).

Option C: If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of faecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination.

Option D: Bacteroides species are present in faeces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for faecal pollution of water.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the fixation technique used for the fixation of fats in the histopathological examination by frozen section technique except:

choices.text: The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain
The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a higher temperature
The majority of the tissue can be appropriately sectioned between -15⁰C to -25⁰C
Fixatives containing alcohols will remove lipids

questions.solution:
The fixation technique used for the fixation of fats in a histopathological examination is the frozen section. The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a lower temperature and not a higher temperature.

Frozen section :

A frozen section ensures that the tissue does not go through routine processing, which can remove the lipids. When the tissue sample goes through rapid freezing, it becomes firmer. The ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned. The temperature range in the cryostat machine usually ranges from 0⁰C to -35⁰C. The majority of the tissue can be appropriately sectioned between -15⁰C to -25⁰C. Tissue samples that contain water can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a lower temperature.

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain. It can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues. It is used in the following conditions:

  • Fat emboli in lung tissue
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin
  • Lipid-rich carcinomas

Fixatives containing alcohols, or routine processing with clearing, will remove lipids. Fixation can be achieved by the following methods:

  • Physical methods - heating, microwaving, cryopreservation
  • Chemical methods - immersion of specimen in fixative, perfusing vascular system with a fixative

 Given below are a few fixatives with their uses:

Technique/Tissue Fixative
Electron microscopy Glutaraldehyde
Trephine biopsy-bone marrow Zenker's fluid (AZF fixative)
GI biopsies Bouin's fixative
Brain Formalin ammonium chloride
Adrenal biopsy Orth's fluid
Pap smear Ethanol

 The most commonly used fixative is 10% neutral buffered formalin.

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text:
The correct heirarchy of steps to be followed during the management of a case of atonic postpartum hemorrhage not responding to uterine massage is:

1. Bimanual compression of the uterus
2. Ligation of uterine artery
3. Manual exploration of the uterus for removing any retained placental fragments
4. B-lynch compression
5. Tamponade using hydrostatic balloon catheter
questions.solution:
Option C represents the correct sequence of steps that are used to control atonic postpartum haemorrhage not responding to the uterine massage.

The following are the steps used in controlling postpartum hemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
    • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
    • Ligation of uterine arteries
    • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
    • Ligation of internal iliac artery
    • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel
  •   Hysterectomy 
Uterotonic drugs Dose for treatment of PPH Dose for prevention of PPH
Oxytocin 10 IU - IM/IV 10 IU - IM/IV
Carbetocin 250 μg - IM 100 μg - IM/IV
Misoprostol 600-1000 μg - oral/rectal/ sublingual 400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral
Ergometrine
/methylergometrine		 200 μg - IM 200 μg - IM/IV

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the uterotonic agents mentioned above. Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is diagnosed with dengue fever. He developed a saddleback fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of this fever pattern?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C

questions.solution:
In the saddleback type fever, which is seen in dengue, acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days.

Pel-Ebstein fever is a fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. (option C)

Continuous fever is characterised by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.(option A)

Remittent fever is characterised by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (option D)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia infection and rat-bite fever)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry staining revealed the findings as shown in the image below. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. The adjuvant treatment of choice for this patient is endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2:

 

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given to patients with tumours that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumours that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy as per the American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines should be considered for patients with positive lymph nodes, HER2-positive disease, tumors >5 mm, triple-negative tumors, or with lympho-vascular invasion.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with complaints of headache, vomiting and neck stiffness for a few days. He had undergone a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement for hydrocephalus a few months back. Which of the following is the most common cause for shunt malfunction?
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the shunt is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following -

  • Shunt obstruction - most common cause for shunt malfunction
  • Shunt infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, most commonly from Staphylococcus epidermidis. 
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Tip migration or malposition
  • Shunt overdrainage (slit ventricle syndrome) - usually occurs after many years
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection or breakage or kinking
  • Inguinal hernia
  • Seizures

Shunt obstruction -

  • It is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.
  • The most common site is the ventricular catheter.
  • Obstruction occurs due to clogging of the shunt by blood, proteinaceous material, choroid plexus, glial adhesions or secondary to infection.
  • The patient comes with features of raised intracranial pressure like headache, vomiting and eye examination showing papilloedema. 
  • Diagnosis is done by CT Brain imaging which shows ventriculomegaly. On performing a lumbar puncture, the CSF flow is found to be slow despite the raised CSF pressure.
  • Treatment is by revision of the shunt.

 

The image below shows the location of the shunt in the brain

 

The image below shows a CT scan of the brain with some proteinaceous material deposited in the ventricles and shunt insitu.

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

Related Pearl: Summary of Transport Across Proximal and Distal Portions of the Nephron

Proximal Tubule
Reabsorption

Secretion 

67% of filtered Na+ actively reabsorbed, not subject to control; Cl– follows passively

All filtered glucose and amino acids reabsorbed by secondary active transport; not subject to control

Variable amounts of filtered PO43- and other electrolytes reabsorbed; subject to control

65% of filtered H2O osmotically reabsorbed; not subject to control

50% of filtered urea passively reabsorbed; not subject to control

Almost all filtered K+ reabsorbed; not subject to control

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Organic ion secretion; not subject to control
Distal tubule
Reabsorption Secretion

Variable Na+ reabsorption, controlled by aldosterone; Cl– follows passively

Variable H2O reabsorption, controlled by vasopressin

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Variable K+ secretion, controlled by aldosterone

questions.text: At around 11.30 PM, a 45-year-old man is wheeled into the casualty with anginal pain for which the consultant advises nitrates. On administration of nitrates, his BP suddenly drops and the patient goes into sudden hypotension. On probing into his medical history, his wife mentions that he has been taking a drug for erectile dysfunction. What is the likely mechanism of the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Erectile dysfunction is treated by phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, and tadalafil. PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to an increased risk of hypotension.

The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection. PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP and are, therefore, used in the management of erectile dysfunction.

Drug interactions of PDE-5 and nitrates- PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP by preventing its degradation and therefore cause vasodilation. Since nitrates also act by increasing cyclic GMP mechanism, they can therefore potentiate the effects of PDE-5 inhibitors. Hence, men treated with PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates are at risk for severe hypotension and syncope.

Adverse effects of PDE-5 inhibitors-

  • The most common side effects reported include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, nasopharyngitis, and dyspepsia. Rare but serious reports of prolonged erections lasting more than 4 hours and priapism (painful erections lasting more than 4 hours) have been reported with PDE5 inhibitors. 
  • Sildenafil and vardenafil also cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision. 

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

questions.text: A new test has been developed to screen for ovarian cancer. The following figure illustrates the distribution of values for this test among two populations. If the researcher chooses values under 30 µg/dL as normal limits for the test, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Some persons without cancer will test positive
All persons with cancer will have a positive test

questions.solution:
The test will be 100% specific as nobody without the disease (i.e. nobody that is within the normal range) would test positive.

There is an overlapping of the normal population and the population with the disease for most screening tests which leads to a compromise between sensitivity and specificity of the test. 

The interval 0 μg/dL to 30 μg/dL includes all values of the normal population, but also some values of the population with cancer; therefore, no value above 30 μg/dL will occur in individuals without the disease.  At this cut-off, the test will be 100% specific.
Some individuals with cancer are missed as they have values between 20 μg/dL and 30 μg/dL.

If the interval of 0 μg/dL to 25 μg/dL is chosen, then some persons with levels above 25 μg will have cancer and others will not. There will be some persons without cancer who will test positive (false-positives) and some persons with cancer will test negative (false-negatives).

The interval of 0 μg/dL to 20 μg/dL will be 100% sensitive as it will detect all cancers: there will be no false-negative tests. The compromise here is that it will be less specific: some persons without cancer will test positive (false positive). Therefore, some confirmation of the test by another more specific method will be necessary before we can draw any conclusion. 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation has the following finding on USG. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an anterior abdominal wall defect through which abdominal contents have herniated (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. This is typical of omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. These are due to the persistence of physiological herniation of the gut or as a part of the OEIS complex (omphalocele, exstrophy, imperforate anus, and spinal abnormality) and cloacal exstrophy. 

 

The image below shows omphalocele.

 

The image below shows gastroschisis (a close differential diagnosis for omphalocele).

 

Option A: Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly - 

 Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 

 

 

Option C: Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. It must be carefully differentiated from nuchal translucency (NT) as both may appear similar. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. 

 The image below shows a newborn with cystic hygroma on the right side of the neck.

 

The image below shows cystic hygroma of the neck in the fetus.

 

Option D: Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. In meningoencephalocele or occult spina bifida with Chiari malformations, the scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign while anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa forms the banana sign. 

 The image shows a newborn with encephalocele. 

 

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign on USG as seen below.

 

The scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign as seen below.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: The given cadaveric cross-section is at which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric cross-section is at the level of the T-10 vertebra.

T-10 vertebral landmarks for the viscera: Lower border of lungs, cardia of stomach, liver, spleen, and sometimes, upper border of the kidney are seen. Inferior vena cava, azygos vein, and descending thoracic aorta can also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: At the level of T-4 lies concavity of aortic arch, azygos vein into SVC, bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk, upper border of the heart and tracheal bifurcation.

Option B: At the level of L-1 lies the pylorus, transpyloric plane, hilum of the left kidney, the origin of renal arteries and superior mesenteric artery, neck of the pancreas and termination of the spinal cord.

Option C: At the level of T-7 lies the inferior angle of the scapula, lower border of the heart & central tendon of the diaphragm.
