questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, you notice a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex,  radiating to the axilla and back. Which of the following changes in the Murmur would you expect to see if the patient is made to squat from a standing position?

choices.text: Variable change depending on age of patient

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, having a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla and back indicates a probable diagnosis of Mitral Regurgitation. 

On squatting from a standing position, systemic vascular resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac size increase. Thus the intensity of murmur would increase

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A 70-year old woman presents with frequent vomiting and a tender swelling noticed in the Scarpa's triangle. She also experiences pain along the anteromedial aspect of the thigh which is relieved by hip flexion. The likely etiology of this pain is due to the compression of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings are suggestive of obturator hernia. The pain from her thigh is due to the compression of the anterior or geniculate branch of the obturator nerve. This is also known as the Howship-Romberg sign. The pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh that is relieved by thigh flexion.

Obturator hernia is also known as skinny old lady hernia or French hernia. It occurs more commonly in thin, elderly, debilitated females.

Predisposing factors are:

  • Women with wider pelvis and more triangular obturator canal
  • Malnutrition
  • Chronic constipation
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Multiparity
  • Ascites
  • Kyphoscoliosis

It occurs through the obturator canal between the superior pubic ramus and obturator membrane. The patients usually present with features of intestinal obstruction, which is often confirmed only on laparotomy. In a few cases, it is seen as a swelling in Scarpa's triangle deep to the pectineus muscle, with limb kept in flexed and abducted position and any movement of the limb resulting in pain. 

The swelling can be missed due to the covering by the pectineus muscle. It is detected through the obturator foramen on vaginal or rectal examination in a few cases. The chances of bowel obstruction and perforations from strangulation are high. 

Treatment involves surgery and repair of the hernial orifice. The defect is best closed by a mesh plug placed just next to the neurovascular bundle. If infected, broad ligament can be used as a plug. Adjunctively, laparoscopic TAPP repair can also be done.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with fungal infection of the sinuses and periorbital region, with significant visual impairment, as shown below. Vascular involvement and thrombosis are seen in the biopsy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, and lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus oryza.

The agents of zygomycosis are angioinvasive. The major clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis. It results from the germination of the sporangiospores in the nasal passages of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels. This causes thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The disease progress to invade the paranasal sinuses, eyes, cranial bone, and brain. It damages blood vessels and nerves, thereby developing edema of the involved facial area, a bloody nasal exudate, and orbital cellulitis.

A culture of nasal discharge, tissue, or sputum will show broad hyphae with uneven thickness, irregular branching, and sparse septations.

Treatment includes aggressive surgical debridement, rapid administration of amphotericin B, and control of the underlying disease.

Other options:

Option A: Coccidioidomycosis primarily includes pulmonary infection. It is caused by Coccidioides immitis. A self-limited influenza-like fever may occur in some individuals. Disseminated disease is seen in less than 1% of the people

Option B: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It presents as a pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis involves infection of the reticuloendothelial system which manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia.

Option D: Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases that are caused by a number of Aspergillus species. It can either present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text:
During a vaccination drive, a 36-year-old pregnant woman with an obstetric score of G4P3L2 comes to get vaccinated. Which of the following vaccines are contraindicated in this woman?
  1. COVID-19
  2. Varicella
  3. Hepatitis A
  4. Rubella
  5. Zoster
questions.solution:
Among the given options, varicella vaccine, rubella vaccine, and zoster vaccine cannot be administered to this patient as they are live vaccines, which are contraindicated in pregnant women.

The live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm to the fetus.

Contraindications for live vaccines:

  • Immune deficiency diseases
  • Suppressed immune responses as a result of 
    • Leukaemia

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who is a chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. The abdominal pain is persistent and intractable. CT-scan revealed pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. The given condition is likely to be caused due to disturbance in which of the following phases of nutrient absorption?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. In chronic pancreatitis, the phase of intraluminal digestion is affected in which proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into forms suitable for absorption. Fat malabsorption in patients with chronic pancreatitis is often associated with steatorrhea.

Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive faecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-coloured stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn disease.

Long-standing malabsorptive disease is accompanied by nutritional deficiency, including weight loss, anemia, osteomalacia, and a tendency to bleed.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

  • Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.
  • Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a known history of hypothyroidism was brought to the emergency with a reduced level of consciousness, bradycardia, and hypotension. Her temperature was 32 degrees celcius. Her capillary blood glucose level is 106 mg/dl. Which of the following would be most useful in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests a case of hypothyroidism presenting in myxedema coma. IV liothyronine is useful in its management.

Myxedema coma refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly. It is often precipitated by drugs (sedatives, antidepressants, anesthetics), infections like pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia, cerebrovascular accidents, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patients present with impaired consciousness, profound hypothermia (which can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. It is associated with a high mortality rate.

Management of myxedema coma is with levothyroxine (T4) or liothyronine (T3). Levothyroxine is given intravenously, while liothyronine can be given via nasogastric or intravenous route. Parenteral hydrocortisone is used to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones. And the precipitating factors are treated symptomatically. Supportive therapy is by correcting the associated metabolic imbalance, external warming(if body temperature is <30 degrees) to prevent circulatory collapse by using space blankets, and ventilatory support if hypercapnia is present.

Other options:

Option A: IV diazepam is used in emergency management of status epilepticus.

Option B: IV 2.5% dextrose is not the most useful drug in this scenario since the patient's capillary blood glucose (CBG) levels are within the normal range

Option D: Slow rewarming with space blankets is used to treat hypothermia of myxedema coma to prevent circulatory collapse.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes to the OPD requesting medications to quit smoking. He complains about feeling helpless and hopeless most of the time since years and also reports having suicidal ideations. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case is well motivated to quit smoking however the patient is suffering from depression and hence the drug of choice is Bupropion (depressed patient wishing to quit smoking).

  • A sustained-release preparation of the antidepressant bupropion improves abstinence rates among smokers and remains a useful option. However, Bupropion decreases the seizure threshold and should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Varenicline, a partial agonist at the α4β2 subtype of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, reduces cigarette craving and improves long-term abstinence rates. It has high receptor affinity, thus blocking access to nicotine, so if the treated smoker relapses, there is hardly any reward, and abstinence is more likely to be maintained.
  • The nicotine withdrawal syndrome can be alleviated by nicotine replacement therapy (e.g., nicotine inhaler and nasal spray, nicotine gum or lozenge, or nicotine transdermal patch). These methods suppress the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. However, most resume smoking over the ensuing weeks or months.
  • The cannabinoid CB1 receptor inverse agonist rimonabant improves abstinence rates and reduces the weight gain seen frequently in ex-smokers. It was found to be linked to depressive and neurologic symptoms and is not approved by the FDA.

questions.text: During your visit to the ER, you notice a patient's leg appearing as shown in the image below. This procedure would have been performed because his differential pressure measurement would have revealed ____________

choices.text: Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 30 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure > 30 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 40 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure > 40 mm Hg

questions.solution:
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 30 mm Hg would be the indication to perform fasciotomy.

The image shows fasciotomy which is done to relieve the pressure in the muscle compartments in patients with compartment syndrome. There is a longitudinal incision present over the swollen leg, lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia. 

The diagnosis of compartment syndrome can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Closed lower limb injuries can increase the pressure within the muscle compartments, leading to compartment syndrome. It is characterized by severe pain, pain on passive movement of the affected compartment muscles, distal sensory disturbance, and the absence of pulses distal to the compartment.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to the compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated.

questions.text:
A woman on oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) should be warned of potential failure of contraception while prescribing which of the following drugs?

1. Valproate
2. Rifampicin
3. Phenytoin
4. Phenobarbitone
questions.solution:
Contraceptive failure in patients on the oral contraceptive pill is likely to occur with rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone.

Rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers and can cause increased metabolism of OCPs leading to contraceptive failure.

Valproate does not cause contraceptive failure. It is an enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the degradation of OCPs and increases their duration of action.

Enzyme inducers Enzyme inhibitors

Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

  • Carbamazepine
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Phenobarbitone
  • Sulfonylureas

Mnemonic: RED VICK

  • Ritonavir
  • Erythromycin
  • Diltiazem

questions.text: A primigravida is being assessed for induction of labor. Her vaginal examination reveals an anterior cervix soft in consistency, cervical length of 3 cms, and dilation of 5 cms. The head of the baby is at -1 station. What would be her modified Bishop's score?
questions.solution:
The Modified Bishop score in this patient is calculated to be 10.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by the cervical length in cm.

From the data given in the question:

  • The position of the cervix is anterior, hence score = 2
  • Cervical length is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Cervical dilatation is 5 cm, hence score = 3
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • The station of the head is –1, hence score = 2

Hence, the Modified Bishop score is 2+1+3+2+2 = 10.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text:
A 50-year old man from Bihar presented with an ulcerated lesion over his arm for 2 months as shown in the image below. He mentioned that it had initially started as a small raised lesion that increased in its size and crusted before the formation of the ulcer. Which of the following statements are true about this condition?
  1. The gold standard for diagnosis is the growth of promastigotes in NNN culture medium.
  2. Amphotericin B can be used where resistance to antimonials is detected
  3. Mucosal lesions are not commonly seen in this form of the condition
  4. Phagolysosomal infection by promastigotes gives rise to the cutaneous lesions
  5. Adult sandflies are nocturnal in their habitat and thrive in dry climates
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing a crusted ulcer with an erythematous rim showing a “volcano sign” is suggestive of an 'oriental sore'/Old World Cutaneous Leishmaniasis. Amphotericin B can be used where resistance to antimonials is detected and mucosal lesions are seen more commonly in mucocutaneous forms, not cutaneous forms.

  • The gold standard for diagnosis is tissue aspirate histopathology
  • Cutaneous macrophage infection by the parasite gives rise to the cutaneous lesions
  • Adult sandflies are nocturnal in their habitat and thrive in wet climates. 

 

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Causative organisms include:

  • Old world leishmaniasis: L. donovani, L.major, and L.tropica
  • New world leishmaniasis: L. mexicana complex and L. braziliensis complex

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

The image given below shows Chiclero ulcer/New World cutaneous leishmaniasis.

 

The image below shows Lutzomyia sandfly responsible for the New World cutaneous leishmanisis.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

  • The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

Given below is the lifecycle of Leishmania donovanii.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Though lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, it is rare in India. It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.

The image below shows bone marrow aspiration from the sternum

Tests to detect leishmaniasis include:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks (delayed-hypersensitivity) after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are:

  • Sodium stibogluconate
  • Miltefosine
  • Amphotericin B

In Bihar, there is resistance to antimony so amphotericin-B-deoxycholate or miltefosine is preferred.

Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a condition when Leishmania donovanii is found in the skin and manifests as dermal lesions. It is usually seen in the kala-azar endemic zones i.e. Bihar, Jharkhand, U.P, West Bengal, Northeastern states of India.

These patients present with erythematous rash and hypopigmented macules similar in appearance and distribution to those of lepromatous leprosy but normally less than 1cm. After a variable period of years or months, diffuse nodulation begins to develop in these macules. The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

The image below shows post-kala-azar cutaneous leishmaniasis. 

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with a 6-month history of fatigue, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath for 3 months. He also complains of pain in his fingertips on exposure to the cold and has digital ulcers. Physical examination reveals crepitations in both lung fields. Pulmonary function testing shows a restrictive pattern. The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. If the compliance of the patient's lung is represented by curve C, what could curves A and B  most likely represent?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of systemic sclerosis with pulmonary fibrosis. Curves B and A will represent emphysema and a normal lung respectively.

Systemic sclerosis present with the following findings - fatigue, joint pain, sclerodactyly, digital ulcers, calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, dysphagia, pulmonary fibrosis, etc

Pulmonary fibrosis presents with a dry cough and dyspnea with physical exam findings of crepitations on auscultation. Fibrosis presents as a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing and a fibrosis lung is less compliant.

  • The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

Hysteresis:

The difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed hysteresis.  

The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis.

the mechanism behind inspiration and expiration curves are shown below.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
You inject lidocaine around a sebaceous cyst prior to excising. Which of the following processes contribute to its local anesthetic action?
  1. Inhibition of Na channel
  2. Potentiation of K channel
  3. Inhibition of K channel
  4. Potentiation of Ca channel
  5. Inhibition of Ca channel
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 5.

The mechanisms of action of local anesthetics like lidocaine include:

  • Inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels
  • Inhibition (not potentiation) of K and Ca channels
  • Inhibition of Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)

However, the main action of local anesthetics is mediated by the inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He gives a history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. On examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of the following arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite. Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults. In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferred where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated.

questions.text:

3. Swyer’s syndrome c. Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis
4. Mullerian agenesis d. Normal uterus and vagina, with streak gonads, and risk of testicular tumor

questions.text: A young patient started neglecting one-half of his body after an accident. He uses only his right side of the body, trims his beard only on the right side of his face, and reads only the right half of the page. There are no apparent primary visual, auditory, or somatosensory defects. This occurs due to an injury in which of the following parts of the brain?

choices.text: Superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere
Inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere
Superior part of the hippocampus and mammillary bodies
Angular gyrus of the representational hemisphere

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is neglecting one-half of his body. This is called unilateral inattention and neglect which occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere.

In our human brain, one hemisphere is specialised for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialised for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

  • Astereognosis - the inability to identify objects by feeling them due to a lesion in the parietal lobe
  • Agnosia - inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognise faces
  • Unilateral inattention and neglect - Patients neglect one-half of their bodies and may experience personal neglect syndrome. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule and a region of the posterior parietal cortex close to the occipital lobe.

The function of the non-dominant side of the parietal lobe is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. It is associated with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object and hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

The functions of the dominant hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy. In this hemisphere, the parietal lobe is concerned with calculation, language, planned movement, and appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

Other options:

Option A: Lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere lead to Wernicke's aphasia. 

Option C: Lesions in the hippocampus, mamillary bodies, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and areas of the forebrain result in memory disturbances.

Option D: Lesions in the angular gyrus of the categorical hemisphere result in anomic aphasia.

questions.text:
Match the following scattergrams with their correlation coefficient.

A) 0
B) -0.5
C) +1
D) +0.5
questions.solution:
Correlation (denoted by r) is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer).

The correlation coefficient is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • +1 or -1 suggests the maximum possible strength of the correlation.
  • Values closer to 1 have greater strength of the correlation.
  • Correlation coefficients greater than +/- 0.5 are suggested as strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.

The sign indicates the direction of correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated, which implies that the variables are associated (Ex: Smoking and lung cancer have a positive correlation ).
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated, which implies that the variables are inversely associated with each other (Ex: Alcohol intake and Malaria have a negative correlation).
  • For example, both -0.88 and +0.88, represent the same strength of the correlation. However, +0.88 suggests a positive correlation, and -0.88 suggests a negative correlation.

 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese female presents with a  2-year history of long periods of amenorrhea, followed by menorrhagia, along with excessive acne and increased facial, axillary, and pubic hair growth. Her prime concern is menstrual irregularity, for which she wants immediate resolution. On further questioning, she also mentions that she wants to have children after a few years. Which of the following will not be an appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a lady in the menstrual age group who is obese and hirsute, with acne and irregular cycles suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease/syndrome (PCOD/ PCOS). Ormeloxifene is not used as a treatment for polycystic ovarian disease.

Ormeloxifene (a selective estrogen receptor modulator), also known as centchroman, is a nonsteroidal contraceptive taken twice weekly as a 30 mg tablet for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It acts by preventing implantation. It can also be used in AUB due to its anti-estrogenic effects. It is contraindicated in PCOS.  

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states. CYP21 mutation and X-linked dominant inheritance patterns have been implicated in familial cases. 

It is characterized by:

Symptoms Signs 
Early adrenarche Obesity at the waistline, BMI>25
Early menarche  Goiter
Initially, normal menstruation followed by oligomenorrhea or periods of amenorrhea followed by menorrhagia  Hirsutism, acne
Infertility due to anovulation  Hypertension in obesity 
Pregnancy loss or high-risk pregnancies  Acanthosis nigricans 
Hyperandrogenism Acne, hirsutism, scalp baldness 

Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

USG findings of PCOS

  • Enlarged ovaries, volume >10 mm3
  • 12 or more follicles of 2–9 mm each placed peripherally (a string of pearls appearance)
  • Endometrial hyperplasia may be present

The image below shows a string-of-pearls appearance on USG indicative of PCOS.

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other options:

Option A: Ethinyl Estradiol + Drospirenone is a 4th generation combined oral contraceptive pill given for PCOD with androgenic features.

Option B: Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, thereby it decreases hyperinsulinemia. It also reduces the free and total testosterone and increases the sex hormone-binding globulin. It rectifies the root cause of the endocrine disturbance to restore ovulation and thereby improves the fertility rate. 

Option C: Spironolactone 100 mg to 200 mg daily has antiandrogenic effects and can be used in the treatment of androgenic features like severe hirsutism. Combination therapy with an oral contraceptive will be helpful in patients with PCOS.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man with head trauma was brought in an unconscious state to the emergency. After some time, the patient regained his consciousness and then he again started to deteriorate rapidly. His head CT is as below. This patient can be managed conservatively if:

Criteria

  1. Clot volume <30 cm3
  2. Maximum thickness <1.5 cm
  3. GCS >8

choices.text: Patient meets either 1 or 2 along with GCS >12

questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image showing a biconvex/lentiform hemorrhage are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect. 

Craniotomy is indicated for EDH. But, patients who meet all of the following criteria may be managed conservatively:

  • Clot volume < 30 cc
  • Maximum thickness < 1.5 cm
  • Glasgow coma score > 8

EDH refers to the accumulation of blood in the potential space between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. It is common in young adults. It is rare in children below 2 years of age because of the plasticity of the immature calvarium, and after age 60 because the dura is adherent to the overlying bone.

The hematoma arises from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal vein and diploic veins may also be implicated.

A lucid interval is not pathognomonic for EDH as other post-traumatic mass lesions like a subdural hematoma, and temporal lobe contusion can also present with a lucid interval. Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

On head CT, the blood clot is bright, biconvex or lentiform in shape, and has a well-defined border. An EDH is typically found over the convexities but may rarely occur in the posterior fossa as well.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with pruritis vulvae and vaginal discharge. After carrying out the speculum examination,  you prescribed a drug. The patient now presents with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting. What will be your next best step?

choices.text: Stop the drug and switch to trichofuran suppositories
Continue the drug and add trichofuran suppositories
Stop the drug and switch to an alternative drug
Continue the drug after taking ondansetron

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the speculum examination showing strawberry cervix are suggestive of trichomoniasis. The standard treatment of a patient with trichomonas infection is metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days, or as a single oral dose of 2g for 1 day (shortened duration). It caused the patient to present with multiple episodes of vomiting. If taken after meals and at bedtime, may reduce the incidence of nausea and vomiting. In case of resistant vomiting, it is advisable to switch to alternative drugs like:

i) Secnidazole 1000mg daily for 2 days, or

ii) Tinidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days.

The treatment of a patient with trichomonas infection in the first trimester: (Metronidazole is best avoided)

  • Vinegar douche (to lower the pH)
  • Trichofuran suppositories
  • Betadine gel

The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection. Regardless of the treatment duration, patients should abstain from sexual activities for 7 days since the last antibiotic dose.

Trichomonas vaginalis is one of the most common causes of vaginal discharge. It is the only protozoan with one stage in its life cycle ie., trophozoite form (no cyst stage is seen). It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with vaginal, urethral or prostatic tissues. It is slightly larger than a leucocyte with four anterior flagella and a single posterior flagellum. It exhibits jerky or twitching motility.

It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4–21 days. Infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum with pH > 4.5,
  • Nearly half the patients who complain of pruritis vulvae harbour this organism
  • Dysuria and frequent micturition
  • Infertility, preterm birth and low-birth-weight infants.
  • 20% of the patients may remain asymptomatic

Males can be asymptomatic or develop non-specific urethritis. It has been also associated with infertility through inflammatory damage to the genitourinary tract or interference with sperm function.

Diagnosis in females is usually easily confirmed by the presence of motile organisms on a wet film. Culture in Feinberg–Whittington medium is the most reliable method but is not routinely done. The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM (cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose) or PEM (plastic envelope medium).

 

Option A or B is unlikely as there is no evidence to support the pregnancy in this patient. Trichofuran suppositories are indicated in the first trimester as Metronidazole is best avoided.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is being assessed for developmental delay. She plays cooperatively in a group, and goes to the toilet alone, but is unable to dress or undress by herself. She tells stories and builds bridges with blocks but hasn’t built a gate with blocks yet. Also, the mother confirms the child hasn’t yet started asking for the meaning of words. What is her developmental quotient?
questions.solution:
The developmental age of the child corresponds to 4 years and the developmental quotient would, therefore, be 57.

The child meets the following milestones corresponding to 4 years:

  • Plays cooperatively in a group
  • Goes to the toilet alone
  • Tells stories
  • Builds bridges with blocks

The child does not meet the following developmental milestones corresponding to 5 years:

  • Dress or undress herself
  • Built a gate with blocks
  • Asking for the meaning of words

So, the developmental age of the child corresponds to 4 years.

DQ = Developmental age x 100⁄Chronological age

DQ = 4/7x100 = 57.14~57

questions.text: What is the optimum temperature for storage of RBCs collected in preservatives?
questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for storage of packed RBCs and whole blood collected in preservatives is +2° to +6° C. This temperature maintains the viability of the cells and prevents bacterial contamination.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on carbamazepine. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to carbamazepine?

choices.text: Stop carbamazepine and start on retigabine

questions.solution:
The dose of carbamazepine should be increased when phenytoin is added because phenytoin can decrease the plasma concentration of carbamazepine when given together.

Phenobarbital, phenytoin may increase the metabolism of carbamazepine by inducing CYP3A4 and thereby reducing its plasma concentration when given together.

Carbamazepine is a derivative of iminostilbene and is considered to be the primary drug for the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic, focal-to-bilateral tonic-clonic, tonic-clonic of unknown onset (generalized tonic-clonic), and focal seizures. It is also used for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.

Other drug interactions of phenytoin:

  • It is an inducer of the enzymes CYP2C8/9, CYP3A4/5, and other CYPs. It is also an inhibitor of CYP2C9/19. 
  • Phenobarbitone can inhibit the metabolism of phenytoin. But the overall interaction is unpredictable as both the drug enhance each other's degradation by enzyme induction.
  • Phenytoin and carbamazepine induce each other's metabolism.
  • Valproate increases the level of unbound phenytoin by displacing the protein-bound form and decreasing its metabolism.
  • Phenytoin increases the metabolism of steroids, oral contraceptives, doxycycline, theophylline, etc by enzyme induction.
  • It produces competitive inhibition of warfarin metabolism. (Increased risk of bleeding when given together)
  • Drugs like chloramphenicol, warfarin, isoniazid, and cimetidine can inhibit the metabolism of phenytoin and cause its toxicity.
  • Sucralfate decreases the absorption of phenytoin by binding to it in the gastrointestinal tract.

Vigabatrin Loss of peripheral vision
Felbamate Fulminant hepatic failure, aplastic anemia
Lamotrigine Hypersensitivity reactions, SJS
Topiramate Paresthesias, renal calculi, weight loss, acute glaucoma
Oxcarbazepine Hyponatremia, SJS
Ezogabine Urinary retention

questions.text: A multigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice that the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's manoeuvre is done for delivery of head in normal labour.

This manoeuvre is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This manoeuvre allows controlled delivery of the head.

 

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A young male was managed with the following cast for a closed fracture of the leg, which was associated with few abrasions over the ankle. According to biomedical waste management, this cast should be disposed of in which of the following bins?
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, used plaster casts, contaminated with body fluids, should be disposed of in a yellow colored bag. All the soiled waste items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts are discarded in the yellow bin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women.

This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 μg/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.

However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 μg/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.

Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man came with painful lesions as shown below. On further probing, he tells you that he had vesicles on his penis 2 days back and that he is allergic to penicillin. On examination, he has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe the blue kit to the patient
Prescribe the red kit to the patient
Prescribe the blue kit to the patient and the partner
Prescribe the red kit to the patient and the partner

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2. It is treated with a red kit in which treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days.

Chancroid is a close differential diagnosis, which presents with multiple, soft painful ulcers and unilateral tender lymphadenopathy. However, vesicles are not seen in the chancroid and the ulcers are deeper with ragged undermined edges.

History of drug allergy to penicillin is relevant only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis. In such a case, they would need to be treated with a blue kit instead of a white kit.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
Arrange the following according to the sequence in which they occur in a chronic cor pulmonale, resulting in RV dysfunction:
  1. Pulmonary hypertension and increased RV afterload
  2. RV dilation
  3. Increased RV wall tension
  4. Vascular remodelling of pulmonary circulatory bed
  5. RV hypertrophy
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events which occur in cor pulmonale resulting in RV dysfunction are:

Vascular remodelling of pulmonary circulatory bed --> Pulmonary hypertension and increased RV afterload --> RV hypertrophy --> RV dilation --> Increased RV wall tension.

Chronic cor pulmonale develops as a result of chronic pulmonary hypertension due to parenchymal lung disorders, primary pulmonary vascular diseases, or conditions leading to alveolar hypoxia. These include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, pulmonary arterial hypertension, chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, interstitial lung diseases like sarcoidosis, etc.

The main pathophysiology behind cor pulmonale is pulmonary hypertension and increased right ventricular (RV) afterload which is sufficient to cause RV dilation with or without hypertrophy. This alters both the structure and function of the RV. In parenchymal lung diseases, primary pulmonary vascular disorders, or chronic hypoxia, the pulmonary vessels undergo vascular remodeling, vasoconstriction, and destruction leading to increased pulmonary artery pressures and increased RV afterload.

Anatomically, the right ventricle is thin-walled, compliant, and can handle volume overload better than pressure overload. Sustained pressure overload eventually leads to RV dysfunction and failure.

Dyspnea is the most common symptom. Other symptoms include pedal edema, abdominal distension due to ascites, the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, an S3 gallop, and a palpable RV heave along the left sternal border. The jugular venous pressures (JVP) are elevated with prominent v waves indicative of tricuspid regurgitation. Other features include hepatomegaly, pulsatile liver, tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and pitting pedal edema.

The ECG in severe pulmonary hypertension shows P-pulmonale, right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy. Spirometry and lung volumes show obstructive and/or restrictive defects seen in parenchymal lung diseases. Echo can be used to measure RV wall thickness and chamber dimensions, while doppler ECHO can be used to assess pulmonary artery pressures. Cardiac catheterization confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and can exclude elevated left-sided pressures as a cause of heart failure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. X-ray abdomen reveals characteristic sign as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows rows of several air-filled spaces between the valvulae conniventes of fluid-filled, dilated small bowel loops, giving a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘string of beads’ appearance, characteristic of small bowel obstruction.

Radiological features of small bowel obstruction:

X-ray:

  • On erect X-ray, there may be presence of more than 2 fluid levels within the dilated small bowel loops.
  • Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.

Ultrasound:

It can detect fluid-filled loops of the small intestine.

CT:

  • The presence of angulated and tethering of the bowel loops on CT may indicate adhesions, most likely due to a neoplasm.
  • Small bowel ‘feces sign’ may be seen due to the presence of faeces-like material in the small bowel loops proximal to the obstruction. It can occur due to prolonged stasis, and water reabsorption.
  • In simple obstruction, a definite point of obstruction, called ‘transition point’ may be seen, with dilated small bowel loops proximally, and collapsed loops distally.
  • In closed-loop obstruction, a U- or V-shaped configuration of the dilated loops may be seen with a fixed radial distribution.
  • A strangulated bowel represents the incarceration of the proximal and distal limbs of mechanical small bowel obstruction, with subsequent ischemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial weakness and pain for the past 2 days. The following signs are seen on examination. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.

In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy. 

In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation. 

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text: A victim of a homicide was found in a ditch. The body is sent for forensic examination and the victim is estimated to have been dead for a period of 15-20 hours. Which of the following changes is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the victim has been dead for 15-20 hours and hence, adipocere is not likely to be seen. Adipocere is a late sign of death that occurs days to months after death.

Adipocere formation or corpse wax is a late sign of death. A wax-like organic substance is formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fat in tissues. It has a greyish-white appearance with a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. But in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 3 to 15 days after death. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    • Cessation of respiration
    • Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death that is observed in the first 12 to 24 hours of death):
    • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    • Eye changes
    • Primary flaccidity of muscles
    • Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    • Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    • Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    • Putrefaction
    • Adipocere
    • Mummification

Other options:

Option A: Suggilation/ Postmortem hypostasis/ Postmortem staining/ Livor mortis refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6-12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in. 

Option B: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. For about half to one hour after death, the rectal temperature falls very little, and then a linear rate of cooling occurs for the next 12-16 hours. 

Option D: Rigor mortis refers to the state of stiffening of muscles and is indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level. It appears 2-3 hours after death.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with a history of chronic ear pain and ear discharge presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as an intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).  Intravenous antibiotic metronidazole is administered. Raised ICP is treated with dexamethasone or mannitol.

Brain abscess has 4 stages:

  • Stage of invasion (initial encephalitis): This stage usually passes unnoticed. Headache, malaise, low-grade fever, and drowsiness are seen.
  • Stage of localization (latent abscess): This is an asymptomatic stage, usually lasting for several weeks. A capsule is formed to localize the pus. 
  • Stage of enlargement (manifest abscess). Enlargement of the abscess (leading to raised intracranial pressure) and the formation of a zone of edema around the abscess lead to an aggravation of symptoms.
  • Stage of termination (rupture of abscess). The abscess expands and ruptures into the ventricle or subarachnoid space resulting in fatal meningitis.

Signs of raised intracranial pressure are headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, papilledema, and coma. 

Characteristic findings of temporal lobe abscess are nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, epileptic fits, contralateral motor paralysis, pupillary changes, and oculomotor palsy. 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.  

Management:

  • Medical:  Intravenous antibiotics (usually metronidazole) are started. Raised intracranial pressure is treated with dexamethasone or mannitol.
  • Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

questions.text:
The following image shows the chemiosmotic mechanism and the bioenergetics involved in biological oxidation. Given below are a few toxic compounds known to inhibit the Electron Transport Chain. Which of these would inhibit the complex marked in the image?
  1. Hydrogen sulfide
  2. Atractyloside
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Oligomycin
  5. Cyanide
  6. Antimycin A
questions.solution:
The inhibitors of Complex IV of the electron transport chain are hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, and cyanide.

Electron transport chain (ETC) is the final pathway by which all the electrons derived from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids are directed toward the final reaction with oxygen to form water and ATP.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has chronic hypertension since 10 years. He has tried three different drugs A, B, and C to control his hypertension over the years. The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)

questions.text:
Match the following.
Section A Section B
1. Granulosa cell tumor a. Schiller-Duval bodies
2. Endodermal sinus tumor b. Walthard cell nest
3. Brenner tumor c. Hobnail cell
4. Clear cell tumor d. Call–Exner bodies
questions.solution:
The correctly matched ovarian tumors with their pathological findings include:

Tumor type HPE finding
Granulosa cell tumor Call–Exner bodies
Endodermal sinus tumor Schiller-Duval bodies
Brenner tumor Walthard cell nest 
Clear cell tumor Hobnail cell

The images below show Call-Exner bodies, a pathognomic of granulosa cell tumor. Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen. 

The image below shows the Schiller-Duval body, which is pathognomic of the endodermal sinus tumor. Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumor. Walthard cell rests are benign clusters of epithelial cells resembling transitional cells.

The image below shows the hobnail cell, which is pathognomic of clear cell ovarian tumors. They are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen.

questions.text: On noticing the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing. Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted CO2 absorbent or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhaled dead space gas 
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau, indicating the transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau that corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveoli. 
  • Following phase III, there is a sharp inspiratory downstroke. It is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A- Esophageal intubation shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero. 

Option B- In the capnograph of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no plateau before the next inspiration with an increased up-slope of phase III. Seen in bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed. 

Option D- A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity suggests malignant hyperthermia. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: A 75-kg woman has a preoperative hematocrit of 35%. How much blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered? (Consider transfusion cut off of Hematocrit as 30%)
questions.solution:
750 ml blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered

The transfusion point can be determined preoperatively from the hematocrit and by estimating blood volume. Patients with a normal hematocrit should generally be transfused only after losses greater than 10–20% of their blood volume. The exact point is based on the patient’s medical condition and the surgical procedure. The amount of blood loss necessary for the hematocrit to fall to 30% can be calculated as follows:

  1. Estimate blood volume
  2. Estimate the red blood cell volume (RBCV) at the preoperative hematocrit (RBCV preop).
  3. Estimate RBCV at a hematocrit of 30% (RBCV 30%), assuming normal blood volume is maintained.
  4. Calculate the RBCV lost when the hematocrit is 30%; RBCV lost = RBCV preop – RBCV 30%
  5. Allowable blood loss = RBCV lost x3.

Blood Volume

Neonates:

  • Premature 95 mL/kg
  • Full-term 85 mL/kg
  • Infants 80 mL/kg

Adults:

  • Men 75 mL/kg
  • Women 65 mL/kg

Estimated blood volume = 65 mL/kg x 75 kg = 4875 mL.

RBCV 35% = 4875 x 35% = 1706 mL.

RBCV 30% = 4875 x 30% = 1462 mL.

Red cell loss at 30% = 1706-1462 = 244 mL.

Allowable blood loss = 3 x 244 mL = 732 ~ 750ml

Therefore, transfusion should be considered only when this patient’s blood loss exceeds 750 ml.

Increasingly, transfusions are not recommended until the hematocrit decreases to 24% or lower (hemoglobin <8.0 g/dL), but it is necessary to take into account the rate of blood loss and comorbid conditions.

questions.text: You come across a report of a 48-year-old male patient and notice a peculiar pattern that both the AFP as well as the CEA are elevated. Which of the following conditions can this patient be having, that might have caused the patient's peculiar report?
questions.solution:
