  • Nonneoplastic conditions like

questions.text:
A boy is wheeled into the casualty following a head-on collision in his motorbike. He speaks inappropriate words, blinks his eyes to a pinch, and flexes his hand away from pain. Only his right pupil is reactive to light. His vitals are PR 52 bpm, BP 80 systolic and peripheries are warm. His upper and lower limb reflexes are intact. Which of the following statements are true regarding his condition?
  1. The patient is having neurogenic shock due to loss of parasympathetic tone
  2. Immediate placement of a cervical collar is a must before starting the examination
  3. A fluid bolus of 2 liters NS must be administered stat
  4. Vasopressor agents and corticosteroids can be given
  5. NCCT brain is indicated as the GCS-P score in this patient is 8
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has bradycardia, hypotension, and warm peripheries, which are suggestive of neurogenic shock. The GCS score in this patient is E2V3M4 = 9. Since only one pupil is reactive to light, one point is deduced and the GCS-P score is 8.

Neurogenic shock is the result of autonomic dysregulation following spinal cord injury, usually secondary to trauma. This dysregulation is due to a loss of sympathetic tone and an unopposed parasympathetic response. The descending sympathetic tracts are disrupted leading to direct damage to the axons and neural membranes in the intermediolateral nucleus, lateral grey mater, and anterior root leading to disrupted sympathetic tone.

Other causes of neurogenic shock include spinal anesthesia, Guillain-Barre syndrome, toxins affecting the autonomic system, transverse myelitis, neuropathies, etc. 

Due to the diminished sympathetic activity, there is bradycardia and vasodilation of the cutaneous vessels leading to warm peripheries. This leads to the pooling of blood in the lower extremities, thereby reducing venous return. As a result, a decrease in JVP, cardiac output, and systolic blood pressure are seen. Bradycardia with hypotension is the characteristic feature of neurogenic shock. 

As he is likely to have sustained neck injury from the RTA, stabilizing it by placing a collar is the first step before checking for airways or circulation due to suspected cervical spinal cord injury. Miami J or Philadelphia collar is commonly used. 

Initial management aims at hemodynamic stabilization. i.v. boluses are relatively avoided in neurogenic shock due to the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema. Revised guidelines state 1 liter of i.v. crystalloids can be given if there is concomitant hypotension. However, the physiologic effects of this shock are not reversed with fluid resuscitation alone. 

Thus, vasopressors like noradrenaline can be given to increase cardiac output and systolic blood pressure. It acts on both alpha-2 G-coupled receptors causing vasoconstriction and beta1 receptors resulting in increased heart rate. Glucocorticoids like methylprednisolone are proven to help if given within 8 hours from the injury. It helps in neurological recovery by reducing edema and preventing intracellular potassium depletion. 

Immediate NCCT brain (within an hour/ immediately after stabilizing the patient) is indicated since GCS is less than 13. 

Differentials of shock - 

Signs  Hypovolemic - Class III  Cardiogenic Neurogenic Anaphylactic Septic - warm Septic - cold
Pulse rate  ↑↑ ↑/↓ ↓ ↑  ↑  ↑/↓
Cardiac output ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓  ↑  ↓
Systolic blood pressure ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓  ↑  ↓
Peripheral vascular resistance ↑ ↑ ↓ ↓  ↓  ↑
Jugular venous pressure ↓ ↑ ↓  ↓  Normal ↑ 

 Spinal shock is characterized by paralysis, decreased tone, and hyporeflexia. It is a temporary physiological shock that starts within minutes after the injury. 

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes the epidemiologic data received from the field investigations and surveillance with the chart given below. Which of the following examples best represent the chart shown in the image?

choices.text: Food poisoning from a lunch party

questions.solution:
Image shows an epidemic with no peak, suggestive of a common source multiple exposure epidemic. Outbreak of gonorrhea spread by a common source like a commercial sex worker is a typical example as the infection usually spreads from one person to other over a period of time, rather than as an explosive increase. 

A common source, multiple exposure epidemic where exposure from the same source may be prolonged - continuous, repeated, or intermittent - and not at the same time or place. There is no single explosive increase in the number of cases. 

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

As opposed to this, common source, single exposure epidemics are called point-source epidemics, eg, food poisoning.

Point-source epidemics:

  • Point source epidemics are also called single exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics.
  • The exposure to the disease agent is brief and all cases develop within one incubation period.
  • In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period and there are no secondary waves.
  • Single exposure, common vector outbreak is explosive with clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time.
  • Infectious agents, environmental pollution, and contamination of food are common causes of point source epidemics.

The common source epidemics are frequently but not always due to exposure to an infectious agent. They can result from contamination of the environment(air, water, soil) by

  • industrial chemicals or pollutants, e.g. Bhopal gas tragedy(air pollution),
  • Minamata disease in Japan(contaminated food chain),
  • Chernobyl tragedy(radiation pollution).


Options B and D - Epidemics of hepatitis A (person-to-person) and an epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) are examples of propagated epidemics that result from transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.  

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following hypothalamic nucleus/nuclei is/are responsible for maintaining the normal body temperature at extreme climatic conditions?
questions.solution:
Anterior and posterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature in response to heat or cold, respectively. 

The anterior hypothalamic-preoptic area contains large numbers of temperature-sensitive neurons, that are believed to function as temperature sensors for controlling body temperature.

Bilaterally in the posterior hypothalamus, approximately at the level of the mammillary bodies, signals from the anterior hypothalamic preoptic area and signals from elsewhere in the body are integrated to control the heat-producing and heat-conserving reactions of the body.

Other options:

Option A: The ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a major satiety center that gives a sense of nutritional satisfaction and inhibits the feeding center.

Option C: The lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a feeding center and operates by exciting the motor drives to search for food.

Option D: Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus controls the circadian rhythms and synchronizes various physiological changes of the body with night and day. It is critical for organizing sleep into a recurring 24-hour circadian pattern of sleeping and waking.

Related Pearl: Functions of Main Hypothalamic Nuclei

 

Hypothalamic Nucleus Function
Supraoptic  Synthesizes vasopressin (ADH)
Paraventricular Synthesizes oxytocin
Preoptic & anterior Nuclei Control parasymphathetic system
Posterior & Lateral Control symphathetic system
Anterior Regulate temperature(response to heat)
Posterior Regulate temperature(response to cold)
Lateral

Initiate eating and increase food intake (Hunger center)
Increase water intake (Thirst center)
Medial

Inhibit eating and reduce food intake (satiety center)

Suprachiasmatic

 Controls circadian rhythm

questions.text:
Match the following delusions with associated syndrome:
Delusion Syndrome
i. Delusion of Love a. Capgras Syndrome
ii. Delusion of Misidentification b. De Clerambault syndrome
iii. Nihilistic Delusion c. Ekbom syndrome
iv. Delusion of infestation d. Cotard syndrome
  e. Othello syndrome
questions.solution:
Delusion and associated syndromes:

  • Delusion of love - De clerambault syndrome
  • Delusion of misidentification - Capgras syndrome
  • Nihilistic delusion - Cotard syndrome
  • Delusion of infestation - Ekbom syndrome

Delusion is a disorder of thought content and is defined as a false belief, based on incorrect inference about exter­nal reality, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof or evidence and despite the fact that other members of the culture do not share the belief.

Note: Restless legs syndrome is also called as Willis-Ekbom disease (RLS/WED). It is a chronic neurosensory disorder that is characterized by a strong urge to move, accompanied by uncomfortable paresthesia in the legs which affects about 5-15 percent of adult people in industrialized countries. Should not be confused with Ekbom syndrome.

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A patient on ART is being co-administered with a drug that is a pharmacokinetic booster without inherent antiviral activity. Which of the following is the drug that is prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
The patient must have been prescribed Cobicistat which is a pure pharmacokinetic booster without any antiviral activity indicated in HIV infection to boost the bioavailability of protease inhibitors.

Cobicistat:

  • It is a CYP3A inhibitor and approved for use along with atazanavir and darunavir in HIV infections.
  • Ritonavir is usually used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer for other protease inhibitors like lopinavir and others, but it has inherent antiviral activity against HIV (Options A and C).
  • Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor against HIV-1 (Option B).
Cobicistat Ritonavir
Specific CYP3A4 inhibition

Potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and a weak inhibitor of CYP2D6
Better tolerated Less tolerated 
Reduced impact on plasma lipids Causes dose-dependent elevation in serum total cholesterol and
triglycerides
Lacks P450 enzyme induction Moderate inducer of P450 enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be activated after a carbohydrate-rich meal?
questions.solution:
Only phosphofructokinase 2 will be activated after a meal.

Phosphofructokinase 2 is a bifunctional enzyme that can phosphorylate fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate during glycolysis. The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown since it has fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase activity.

When there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. 

Other options:

HMG CoA lyase is an enzyme involved in ketogenesis which occurs during the fasting state.

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis which is favored by glucagon during the fasting state.

Insulin indirectly inhibits β-oxidation by activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) and increasing the malonyl-CoA concentration in the cytoplasm, which inhibits carnitine acyltransferase (Fatty acid oxidation).

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used in a patient with severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Device 2 shown in the above image represents a cochlear implant, which can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. (Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.)

The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant. Microphone, speech processor, and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant, which remains outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.


Other options: 

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia. Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA, that combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear – a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Bone-anchored Hearing Aids are used:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal are associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids.
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  • In Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • In Single-sided deafness

Device 3 is a picture of a stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes is structurally intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient presented with a history of progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past 2 years. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve on exercise. An x-ray image of his spine was taken and is given below. Which of the following characteristic findings seen from the image help in clinching the diagnosis?

1. Dagger spine appearance

2. Bullet-shaped vertebra

3. Trolley-track appearance

4. Squaring of the vertebral body

5. Rugger jersey spine
questions.solution:
A young male adult presenting with a history of lower backache and early morning stiffness, relieved upon exercising is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. A radiograph of the spine shows a dagger spine, trolley-track appearance, and squaring of the vertebral body, which aid in confirming the diagnosis. 

The dagger sign is noted as a linear increased density running along with the spinous processes due to ossification of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments. In addition, there are two more lateral vertical linear lines, which represent the ossification of paraspinous ligaments, resulting in a rail-road track sign. The three vertical ossified lines together make up the trolley-track sign.

Important radiological features of ankylosing spondylitis: 

  • Cardinal sign/ earliest sign on x-ray is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint can be seen.
  • The involvement of these joints is usually bilateral and symmetrical. 
  • Early detection by MRI pelvis shows subchondral bone marrow edema. 

CT image shows spine ankylosis continuously involving all the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies:

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

 

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune

HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text:
Which among the following is/are examples of prescriptive screening?
  1. Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population
  2. Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  3. Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  4. Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever
  5. Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Options 2, 3 and 5 are examples of prescriptive screening.

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.
Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. A few examples are: 

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
  • Screening for deafness in school children

 

Options 1 and 4 are examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. 

Other type of screening:

  • Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

  • High-risk or Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests.
    Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families

questions.text: At a crime scene, you notice the following wound on the victim's body. What is the type of wound and the likely weapon used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bigger wound than the usual diameter of a bullet with everted margins and bleeding around the wound due to tissue protrusion is suggestive of an exit wound from a revolver.

Firearm wounds are of two fundamental types: wounds of entry and wounds of exit.

The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.

To determine the range of firing, the following parameters are used:

  • Entry wound size and shape
  • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
  • Blackening, tattooing, singeing of hair, abrasion collar, and grease collar
Characteristics Contact shot Close Shot Near Shot Distant Shot
Range  In-touch with skin 2.5-7.5 cm 30-60 cm > 60 cm
Size Largest size Bullet size Smaller Smallest
Shape Stellate Circular Circular Circular
Blast effect
Muzzle end imprint +ve -ve -ve -ve
Edge eversion +ve -ve -ve -ve
Other findings
Blackening -ve +ve -ve -ve
Tattooing -ve +ve +ve -ve
Singeing -ve +ve -ve -ve
Abrasion collar -ve +ve +ve +ve
Grease collar -ve +ve +ve +ve

Option A: Entry wounds from revolvers are smaller than exit wounds. The edges are inverted with bruising, abrasion, and grease collar.

The image given below shows an entry wound from a revolver with an abrasion collar.

Option B: An entry wound of a shotgun from a mid-range or long-distance shows the following findings a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole.

Option C: Usually shotguns do not have an exit wound except in contact wounds, or tangential wounds.

questions.text: On applying firm sliding pressure on unblistered skin in a bullous eruption, the epidermis gets separated from the dermis in some conditions, as shown in the image given below. In which of the following conditions is this sign not seen?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image, which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin is called Nikolsky's sign. This sign is not elicited in epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

In Nikolsky's sign, a tangential/lateral pressure applied on the affected, perilesional or normal skin around the blister, results in separation between the upper and lower layers of the epidermis, producing an erosion. It is positive when there is extension of the blister with or without removal of epidermis in the tested area. This is because the underlying pathology is common to the affected as well as the normal skin.


Nikolsky's sign is found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome(SSSS)
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Bullous eruptions in chikungunya infection
  • Severe cases of acute graft vs host disease

Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid and generalized epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Nikolsky's sign can be wet or dry depending on the underlying type of skin that is seen after elicited after applying the pressure. Active pemphigus vulgaris will elicit a wet sign while a dry sign is seen with pemphigus foliaceus or in reepithelialisation beneath a pemphigus vulgaris blister.

Marginal Nikolsky’s sign occurs when there is an extension of erosion onto the normal skin, surrounding the lesion. This is elicited by rubbing the skin surrounding the existing lesions.

Direct Nikolsky’s sign is elicited by the induction of erosions on the normal skin that are far from the lesions.

Microscopic Nikolsky’s sign may be a better and sensitive method for rapid diagnosis of epidermal acantholysis. It refers to the classical microscopic changes for pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus in the epidermis, that can be confirmed by a skin biopsy.

Note:

False Nikolsky’s sign/Sheklakov’s sign is positive in sub-epidermal blistering disorders like:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Cicatricial pemphigoid
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous systemic lupus eythematosis

It is seen after pulling the peripheral remnant roof of a ruptured blister, thereby extending the erosions onto the surrounding normal skin, which are limited in size, do not extend spontaneously and heal rapidly.

Pseudo-Nikolsky sign/epidermal peeling sign occurs where epidermal separation is due to the necrosis of epidermal cells, instead of acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign. A pseudo-Nikolsky sign can be elicited only in affected areas of the skin. This sign is positive in:

  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Some burn cases

Nikolsky's phenomenon is elicited on palpation by feeling the movement of the detached epidermis over the dermis. This results in the formation of blisters after some time instead of an immediate reaction to form Nikolsky's sign.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had HR - 120 with a slow, irregular respiratory effort. There is some flexion of extremities, grimace and cyanotic limbs with a pink body. The APGAR score would be:
questions.solution:
The APGAR score will be 6.

2 - HR - 120

1 - a slow, irregular respiratory effort.

1 - Some flexion of extremities

1 - Grimace

1 - Cyanotic limbs with a pink body

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the physiology of lactation?
  1. High levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy make the breast tissue unresponsive to the prolactin hormone.
  2. Insulin, thyroxine, and growth hormone play an important role in lactogenesis.
  3. Prolactin is the major galactokinetic hormone.
  4. Oxytocin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone.
  5. The drug metoclopramide improves milk production by increasing prolactin levels.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 5 represent the correct statements.

High levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy make the breast tissue unresponsive to the prolactin hormone. When these hormonal levels start falling after the delivery of the baby, the prolactin hormone starts acting on the mammary glands to produce milk (lactogenesis).

Insulin, thyroxine and growth hormone also play an important role in lactogenesis.

The ejection of milk is referred to as galactokinesis. Oxytocin is the major hormone that is responsible for the process of milk ejection.

Prolactin is the single most important hormone responsible for the maintenance of lactation (galactopoiesis). 

Galactagogues like metoclopramide, sulpiride and domperidone (dopamine antagonists) improve milk production by increasing prolactin levels. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

Proteins and polypeptide hormones

  • Large proteins (> 50 amino acids)
    • Anterior pituitary hormones: FSH, LH, GH, Prolactin
    • Parathyroid hormone
    • Insulin
  • Small peptides (< 50 amino acids)
    • Posterior pituitary hormones: Oxytocin, ADH
    • ACTH
    • Glucagon

Steroid hormones

  • Cortisol and aldosterone
  • Estrogen and progesterone
  • Testosterone
  • DHEA

Derivatives of a specific amino acid

  • Tyrosine
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Catecholamines
  • Tryptophan
    • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • Melatonin
  • Arginine
    • Nitric oxide

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 23-year old healthcare worker presented with a feeling of depressed mood that lasts most of the day, from her late adolescence till date. She has feelings of worthlessness, has no interest to do anything and stays away from interacting with others. She has never experienced a manic episode and does not have any agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of persistent depressed mood since adolescence, that lasts most of the day, with feelings of worthlessness, withdrawal from society, loss of interest without psychomotor agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history is suggestive of dysthymia.

Dysthymia is a persis­tent depressive disorder that is characterised by the presence of:

  • Insidious onset
    • Early: <21 years, more common
    • Late: > 21 years
  • Depressed mood that lasts most of the day, almost continuously.
  • Associated feelings of inadequacy, guilt, irritability, and anger
  • Withdrawal from society
  • Loss of interest, inactiv­ity, lack of productivity
  • Inertia, lethargy, and anhedonia are characteristi­cally worse in the morning

The disorder is more common in women and young people. It frequently coexists with other mental disorders, like major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder. 

The DSM-5 diagnosis criteria for dysthymia includes:

  • Presence of a depressed mood most of the time for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents)
  • Presence of 2 or more features of poor appetite/overeating, insomnia/hypersomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness or poor concentration.
  • Should not have symptoms that are part of major depressive disorder like disturbances in appetite and libido, psychomotor agitation or suicidal thoughts
  • Absence of any other medical illness or substance use that can cause this condition.
 

Treatment includes:

  1. Cognitive therapy
  2. Behaviour therapy
  3. Insight oriented psychoanalytic therapy
  4. Interpersonal therapy
  5. Family and group therapies
  6. Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs, venlafaxine and bupropion

Other options:

Double Depression is a condition with the presence of major depressive disorder along with dysthymia.

Cyclothymia is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance with many periods of hypomania and of depression.

Patients with minor depressive disorder have a euthymic mood in between the episodes, but patients with dysthymia have virtually no euthymic periods.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

questions.text: A pregnant woman came to the emergency department with complaints of vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain and several episodes of vomiting. USG was done and it appears as given below. Which of the following features is not typical of this condition?

choices.text: Positive immunostaining of p57KIP2 nuclear protein
Human chorionic gonadotropin levels of > 1 lakh mIU/mL

questions.solution:
The USG scan shows a "snowstorm appearance" which is characteristic of a complete mole. It is negative for p57KIP2 nuclear protein on immunostaining. p57KIP2 is positive in a partial mole.

 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding for the past 4 months. She is not on any medications and has a family history of endometrial cancer. On transvaginal ultrasound, the endometrial thickness is 2 mm but a focal area shows 5 mm of endometrial thickness. Which of the following is the gold standard test to diagnose the cause of bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Fractional curettage of the endometrium and endocervix
Dilatation and curettage of the endometrium
Endometrial sampling using Pipelle/ vabra aspirator

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of postmenopausal bleeding, the transvaginal ultrasound shows a focal area with 5 mm of endometrial thickness. The gold standard investigation for focal lesions causing post-menopausal bleeding is hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy. 

In the given scenario the overall endometrial thickness is 2 mm. However, if the overall endometrial thickness would be >4 mm, then the gold standard investigation would be fractional curettage or dilatation and curettage. Since the question only mentions a focal abnormality, hysteroscopy and selective biopsy is a better choice for this patient. 

Menopause is defined as the absence of menstruation for one year after the age of 40 years. But it is usually seen around 45 to 47 years of age. Any vaginal bleeding that occurs after menopause or even after just 6 months of amenorrhea in menopausal age group women is defined as postmenopausal bleeding. 

All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Investigations used for diagnosing the cause of postmenopausal bleeding:

Outpatient procedures - 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation that checks for endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of >4mm calls for further investigation by endometrial biopsy.
  • Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Inpatient procedures - 

  • Fractional curettage (dilatation and curettage) of the endometrial and the endocervical tissue helps to know the site of malignancy, the extent of spread, and also staging of the tumor. It is the best test to perform if cancer is suspected as the cause of bleeding. This requires general anesthesia.
  • Hysteroscopic inspection & selective biopsy is the gold standard procedure to diagnose focal endometrial lesions. It can be performed as an outpatient procedure as well.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: While undergoing a surgical procedure under halothane anesthesia, a patient suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Following prompt measures, the patient recovers. Considering this history, which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing hyperthermia and muscle rigidity while undergoing a procedure under halothane anesthesia is suggestive of an episode of malignant hyperthermia. Desflurane should be avoided in malignant hyperthermia.

Inhaled anesthetics, such as halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, and methoxyflurane, and depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, are known to trigger malignant hyperthermia; hence, these drugs should be avoided in a patient with prior history of malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in the skeletal muscle, resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Susceptible patients are those with a positive family history (inherited as an autosomal dominant trait) and those with congenital myopathies.

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for the management of malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in Gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule:

A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

In this scenario, the sufferer has been a victim of mob violence and the sequence of injuries would be as mentioned below.

  •  Correct sequence of the injuries in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a patient with pyromania, who died due to burns sustained in a house fire. Presence of which of the following will indicate that the burns are postmortem in nature?
questions.solution:
Presence of blisters with thin, clear fluid is indicative of postmortem burns.

Blisters formed in postmortem burns are pale yellow with thin, clear fluid and dry, hard, yellow base.  Antemortem burns contain serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. Base is red and inflamed.

Option A: Marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes is called a vital reaction. This is characteristic of antemortem burns.

Option C: Curling's ulcer (stress ulcer) is an acute mucosal erosion resulting as a complication from severe burns commonly seen in the duodenum. They are seen in cases of antemortem burns.

Option D: In antemortem burns, a zone of hyperemia (line of redness), of variable width, is present at the edge of the burnt area. It is due to capillary dilatation.

Related Pearl: Differences between antemortem and postmortem burns

 

Characteristics Antemortem burns Postmortem burns
Line of redness Present Absent
Vital sign Present Absent
Vesication / Blister Present and true, contains serous fluid

Present but are false, contains PM gases +/- thin clear fluid
Reparative process Present Absent
Internal organs Congested

Usually burnt+emits peculiar odor
Blood colour Cherry red due to CO Normal
Curling’s ulcer Present Absent
Inflamed Payer’s patches Present Absent

Carbon/ soot particles in the trachea, bronchus

 Present  Absent

Peripheral zone of burn 

 Shows an increase in enzyme reaction Does not show an increase in enzyme reaction

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Mendelsohn maneuver is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation.

Mendelsohn maneuver is a form of a supraglottic swallow. It is done by voluntarily holding the larynx at its maximum height to prolong the duration of the cricopharyngeal opening. It has been used to treat patients with pharyngeal dysphagia.

Post-laryngectomy rehabilitation aims at establishing communication in a post-laryngectomy patient. Various methods used in these include:

  • Written language
  • Aphonic lip speech
  • Esophageal speech
  • Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic device
  • Tracheoesophageal speech facilitated by Blom-Singer and Panje prostheses

Transoral pneumatic device is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

Blom-Singer prosthesis and Panje prosthesis are types of tracheoesophageal prosthesis. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) involves a one-way valve that is inserted through a previously-created tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, the exhaled air is shunted through the TEP into the esophagus, where it induces vibration of the upper esophagal sphincter, which is responsible for phonation. It generates the most intelligible, fluent, natural-sounding voice in contrast to other laryngeal speech methods.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following structures can result in inability to extend the elbow, wrist and fingers?
questions.solution:
The inability to extend the elbow, wrist and fingers is seen in radial nerve injury. The structure marked as 3 is the radial nerve. It divides into the posterior interosseous nerve and the superficial radial nerve in the elbow.

1- Median Nerve

2- Ulnar nerve

4- Medial brachial cutaneous nerve

The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It mainly supplies the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Branches of the radial nerve:

  • In the axilla and the radial groove- It supplies the triceps muscles.
  • Proximal to the lateral epicondyle- nerve to brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis brevis

At the tip of the lateral epicondyle, the nerve divides into the superficial radial nerve and posterior interosseous nerve. Posterior interosseus nerve supplies the supinator, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, abductor pollicis longus, and extensor pollicis brevis. 

Radial nerve injuries

Very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, crutch palsy, extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand are lost.

In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.

Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. There is also a radial extension of the wrist.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: During the blood sample collection in a diabetic patient, gray top tubes are used for plasma glucose estimation because fluoride is an inhibitor of which of the following glycolytic enzymes?
questions.solution:
During the blood sample collection for plasma glucose estimation in a diabetic patient, gray top tubes are used for plasma glucose estimation because it contains sodium fluoride and fluoride is an inhibitor of enolase.

Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes:

  • Fluoride inhibits enolase
  • Iodoacetate inhibits glyceraldehyde 3 PO4 dehydrogenase
  • Arsenate inhibits phosphoglycerate kinase

Note:

Sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate are added to the blood sample to estimate glucose. Fluoride inhibits the glycolytic enzyme enolase and hence halts the process of glycolysis. By doing so, it prevents blood glucose levels from being falsely estimated as low. Potassium oxalate is the anticoagulant added alongside with sodium fluoride.

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme

Arsenate Phosphoglycerate kinase
Fluoride Enolase

 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme

Arsenite

Malonate Succinate dehydrogenase

 

Inhibitors of electron transport

Complex Inhibitors

Complex II TTFA, Carboxin, Malonate
Complex III BAL, Antimycin A
Complex IV Hydrogen sulphide, Carbon monoxide, Cyanide

Agent Mechanism
Atractyloside Inhibits ADP and ATP Transporter
Oligomycin Blocks flow of protons through Fo complex

questions.text: Exhumation of a grave revealed only a remnant pelvis bone. All of the following options point towards the pelvis belonging to a male except?
questions.solution:
Broad and round pelvic cavity is found in a female pelvis. The male pelvic cavity is conical and funnel-shaped.

Differences between male and female pelvis:

Characteristic Male pelvis Female pelvis
General Morphology Massive,  rougher, marked muscle attachments Less massive, slender, smoother
Overall shape Deep funnel Flat bowl
Preauricular sulcus Narrow, shallow Broad, deep
Acetabulum Large, wider, deeper Small, narrower

Body of pubis

Narrow, triangular, thick

Broad, square
Obturator foramen

Large, oval with base upward

Small, triangular with apex forwards

Greater sciatic notch

Smaller, narrower, deeper

Larger, wider, shallower
Ischial Tuberosity Inverted Everted, more widely separated
Pelvic Brim Heart-Shaped Circular or elliptical
Pelvic outlet Smaller Larger

Sacroiliac articulation

Large extends to 21/2 to 3 vertebrae

Small, oblique, extends to 2 to 21/2 vertebrae

Sacroiliac joint surface

Large and less sharply angulated

 

L-shaped and elevated anteriorly

 

Sacrum

Longer, narrower, with more evenly distributed curvature, promontory well marked. Body of first sacral vertebra larger.

 

Shorter, wider; upper
half almost straight, curve forward in the lower half, promontory less marked. Body of first sacral vertebra small

questions.text:
Match the following X-ray with their diagnosis
  1. Chauffeur's fracture
  2. Boxer's fracture
  3. Bennet's fracture 
  4. Rolando fracture
questions.solution:
Bennett’s fracture-dislocation occurs at the base of the first metacarpal bone and is commonly due to punching.

Rolando fracture - intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Boxer's fracture- a fracture at the neck of 5th metacarpal 

Chauffeur fracture - fracture of the radial styloid process.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text:
For which of the following can the instrument that is shown in the image be used?
  1. To hold fascia and galea aponeurotica in craniotomy
  2. To clamp the arterial wall of larger arteries during dissection
  3. To hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy
  4. To hold the bowel for anastomosis 
  5. To hold skin flaps and the bladder wall
questions.solution:
The given image is of Allis' tissue forceps. It is used to hold skin flaps, fascias, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea, and bladder wall. Delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls are avoided due to the risk of tear. So, Allis' forceps can be used to hold fascia and galea aponeurotica in craniotomy, to hold skin flaps & bladder wall and to hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy.

 Identifying Points:

  • The distal blades are not opposing each other.
  • The tip has got teeth in each blade that are opposing.
  • The proximal part has a ratchet/lock.  

Other important forceps in surgery - 

i) Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in the proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

ii) Babcock’s forceps:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc.

iii) Kocher’s hemostatic forceps:

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel. 

iv) Lister’s sinus forceps 

  • Used for blunt dissection.
  • During Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.
  • Used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

v) Sponge holding forceps: 

  •  Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Removing laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during operation of hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity.
  • To hold the cervix during cerclage

vi) Desjardin’s choledocholithotomy forceps: 

  • Used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during the removal of kidney, ureteric, or bladder stones.

This is a long and slender instrument. There are finger bows but no catch. The shaft is curved. The blades are small, without serrations, and fenestrated centrally. 

vii)  Cord holding forceps typically used to hold spermatic cords.

viii)  Pile holding forceps used to hold hemorrhoids.

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity?
  1. Contact dermatitis
  2. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  3. Multiple sclerosis
  4. Atopic dermatitis
  5. Psoriasis
  6. Serum sickness
questions.solution:
The examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity:

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Psoriasis

Other options:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia - Type II
  • Atopic dermatitis - Type I
  • Serum sickness - Type III

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A 60-year-old man underwent a diagnostic colonoscopy and developed severe abdominal pain and bloating 2 hours after the procedure. His vitals were stable but a tympanic note was present all over the umbilical region. CT was done and appears as given below. The next best step in his management is?

choices.text: Laparoscopic closure of the colon with diversion

questions.solution:
In the given case, the patient has sustained iatrogenic colonoscopic perforation and the given CT image shows free air in the anterior abdominal cavity suggesting a pneumoperitoneum. It is a surgical emergency and the patient is symptomatic, hence immediate laparoscopic exploration is the mainstay in managing these cases. 

Iatrogenic colonoscopic perforations typically occur by mechanical trauma (due to increased shaft tip pressure exerted), barotrauma (excessive air insufflation), or electrocautery injury (in therapeutic procedures). 

Pneumoperitoneum is the presence of free gas within the peritoneal cavity but outside the viscera.

The most common cause of pneumoperitoneum is Bowel perforation ( >90% of the cases).

  • Gastric and posterior duodenal perforations are seen in long-standing cases of peptic ulcers.
  • Intestinal perforations are seen with ischemia, inflammation, diverticula, or obstruction (Ex:- Colon Carcinoma).
  • Other causes also include iatrogenic, penetrating injuries, prolonged mechanical ventilation, peritoneal dialysis, etc.

Clinically, they present with acute abdomen having severe diffuse abdominal pain, distension, vomiting, fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea. If the leak is contaminated, then features of peritonitis like fever, abdominal rigidity, guarding, and rebound tenderness can also be seen. This might later lead to septic shock and even death, if not intervened early.

The diagnostic evaluation of most patients begins with upright radiographs of the chest and abdomen. An erect chest X-ray is the preferred view which shows ‘air beneath the diaphragm’. However, CECT is the initial and the most sensitive investigation if the vitals are stable and are used to detect minimal pneumoperitoneum. 

It is mainly managed by:

  • Initially administering intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, correction of electrolyte balance.
  • Early surgical intervention/laparotomy to stop further contamination of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Conservative management is rarely advised and can be considered in spontaneously sealed small perforations.

questions.text: A patient has serum bilirubin of 4.9 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dl. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with elevated serum bilirubin and serum creatinine as it undergoes Hofmann elimination.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous non-enzymatic organ-independent degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg (not <375) is an indication of mechanical ventilation.

Indications of mechanical ventilation:

Directly measured indices

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mmHg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mmHg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices

  • PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–aO2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • Vd/Vt >0.6 (Ratio of physiologic dead space over tidal volume)

Clinical indices

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are false about transfusion-associated malaria?
  1. Sporozoite is the infective stage of the parasite.
  2. Pre-erythrocytic stage is not present.
  3. It may be associated with severe complications and relapses.
  4. It has a shorter incubation period compared to mosquito-borne malaria.
  5. It requires radical treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3 and 5 are false. In transfusion-associated malaria, trophozoite is the infective stage (1). It does not show relapses (3) and does not require radical treatment (5).

Transfusion-transmitted malaria:

  • This condition occurs when a person rcieves blood infected with the malarial parasite.
  • The parasite may survive in stored blood for 1 to 2 weeks.
  • Unlike mosquito-borne malaria where sporozoites enter the blood,here transfused RBCs containing the trophozoites enter the patient’s (recipient’s) blood directly. Hence, there is no pre-erythrocytic stage and the incubation period is usually shorter than mosquito-borne malaria.
  • The patient may develop severe complications.
  • However, hypnozoites are absent and there are no relapses, hence no radical treatment is required.

Other conditions where the trophozoites directly cause the infection include: congenital malaria (due to transplacental transmission from mother to fetus), renal transplantation, and shared syringes among drug addicts.

Related Pearl: Comparison between mosquito-borne and transfusion-transmitted malaria.

  Mosquito-borne malaria Transfusion transmitted malaria
Mode of transmission Mosquito bite Transfusion of infected blood or blood products
Infective stage Sporozoite Trophozoite
Pre-erythrocytic stage Present Absent
Incubation period Long Short  
Complications Comparatively less Associated with severe complications
Hypnozoites May be seen in infection with P. vivax and ovale Absent
Relapse May occur Does not occur
Radical treatment Required Not required

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient presents with severe malnutrition and diarrhea. His medical history states that he has undergone massive small bowel resection and has only 45 cm of his small bowel remaining. Parenteral nutrition is started but he is soon diagnosed with refeeding syndrome. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities are expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes refeeding syndrome and the electrolyte abnormalities seen are hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hypernatremia, and hypokalemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that may occur due to rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients. It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter.

With refeeding, a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate stimulates insulin release, which results in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. The electrolyte disturbances seen in refeeding syndrome include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypernatremia
  • Hypokalemia

However, severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion.

These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention of refeeding involves correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance, administering thiamine and increasing calorie intake gradually.

questions.text: 70 CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of which of the following?
questions.solution:
CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure and fragile X–associated tremor/ataxia.

Normally, the FMR1 gene is methylated and silenced, and the number of CGG repeats remains < 55. However, abnormalities in this gene lead to the accumulation of CGG-containing FMR1 mRNAs, which are toxic to the cell. Depending on the type of mutation, there are 2 distinct syndromes:

  • Fragile X ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) and Fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure: 55-200 repeats (premutation) which causes gain of function.
  • Fragile X syndrome (FXs): 200- 4000 repeats (full mutation) leading to loss of function.

More than half the individuals with FXTAS develop a progressive neurodegenerative syndrome starting in their 6th decade. It is characterized by intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia and may progress to Parkinsonism.

Fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure

Women affected with fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure have menstrual irregularities and decreased fertility. FSH levels are elevated, and antimüllerian hormone levels are decreased which are markers of declining ovarian function. They also develop menopause approximately 5 years earlier than controls.

Option B: Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with deletion of paternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the maternal allele.

Option D: Friedreich ataxia is due to GAA repeat sequences in the noncoding regions.

questions.text:
The brain autopsy of a 60-year old man showed abnormal intranuclear glycogen deposits and specific macroglial cells called Alzheimer's type 2 astrocytes in the grey matter. Which of the following conditions can these cells be found in?
  1. Wilson's disease
  2. Hepatic encephalopathy
  3. Parkinson's disease
  4. Alzheimer's disease
  5. Progressive Multifocal LeukoEncephalopathy
questions.solution:
The presence of Type 2 Alzheimer's astrocytes is seen in Wilson's disease and hepatic encephalopathy. 

Type 2 Alzheimer's astrocytes are reactive macroglial cells seen exclusively in the grey matter. It is mainly seen in individuals with long-­standing hyperammonemia due to chronic liver disease, Wilson disease, or hereditary metabolic disorders of the urea cycle. 

In a hyperammonemia state, the enzyme glutamine synthetase detoxifies ammonia through the amidation of glutamate producing glutamine in the process. Swelling occurs in these astrocytes due to the increased intracellular glutamine levels which induce osmotic stress on the cell resulting in edema. It also causes free radical injuries resulting in the occurrence of the given cells in the brain. 

Microscopically these reactive astrocytes demonstrate enlarged pale nuclei, due to inconspicuous chromatin granules, with one or two sharply demarcated PAS-positive bodies adjacent to the nuclear membrane. Intranuclear glycogen droplets as inclusion bodies are also seen. 

These cells are not related to Alzheimer's disease but were coined by the same neuroscientist who first described Alzheimer's disease. 

 

Other options - 

Parkinson's disease - They contain neurons with intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins known as alpha-synuclein. 

 

Alzheimer's disease - They are characterized by the presence of neurofibrillary tangles inside the neurons. These are composed of silver-staining neuronal cytoplasmic fibrils of abnormally phosphorylated tau protein. 

 

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy has Alzheimer's type I astrocytes which are enlarged multinucleated astrocytes.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non severe Clostridium difficile colitis is :
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non-severe Clostridium difficile colitis is oral fidaxomicin. 

Management of Clostridium difficile infection according to SHEA and IDSA 2021 guidelines
 Nonfulminant  disease- Initial episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
 Nonfulminant  disease- recurrent episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
Bezlotoxumab can be used as an adjunctive
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) without ileus  Oral vancomycin plus intravenous metronidazole 
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) with ileus  Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) or rectal vancomycin

Fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin because it has less relapse rates.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used for taking samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for a Pap smear. Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction.

The instruments used for a pap smear are summarized in the image below.


The Pap/ Papanicolaou test is used for screening cervical neoplasia. The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation but can be done at any other time as well. 24-48 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications. The Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol. After fixing the slide for 30 minutes, it is air dried and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colorful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Other options:

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely.

Option D: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behavior. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.
