questions.text: A farmer presents with lesions on his hand as seen in the image below. He gives a history of a thorn prick a few days ago. Histological examination of the lesion showed sclerotic bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing warty lesions on the hand and the presence of sclerotic bodies suggests the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a type of subcutaneous mycoses caused by fungi of the genus Fonsecae and Cladophialophora. It can cause different patterns of lesions like verrucous, nodular, cicatricial, ulcerated, and tumorous.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of yeast-like sclerotic bodies on KOH mount or by culture on Sabouraud agar.

The image given below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
Match the following egg characteristics with the corresponding organism
  1. An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is bile stained
  2. An egg that does not float in saturated salt solution and is bile stained
  3. An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is non-bile stained
  4. An egg that does not float in when unfertilized, and floats when fertilized

 

  1. Ancylostoma duodenale
  2. Ascaris lumbrlcodes
  3. Trichuris trichiura
  4. Taenia solium pork tapeworm
questions.solution:
1. An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is bile stained -Trichuris trichiura
  2. An egg that does not float in saturated salt solution and is bile stained - Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  3. An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is non-bile stained - Ancylostoma duodenale
  4. An egg that does not float in when unfertilized, and floats when fertilized - Ascaris lumbrlcodes

 

Helminths whose eggs do not float in the saturated solution

  • Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Eggs of Taenia solium and Taenia saginata
  • Eggs of all intestinal flukes

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A tanner presents to the OPD with fever and  a lesion near the wrist as  shown in the image. The lesion appeared as a swelling and became vesicular over 3-4 days and started oozing blood-stained discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the image showing necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

It is commonly seen in tanners or hide porters who come in contact with infected animal hide and skins.

Malignant pustule is seen in infection of Bacillus anthracis.

In cutaneous anthrax, the lesion starts as a papule 1-3 days after infection and becomes vesicular, containing fluid that may be clear or blood-stained.

The whole area is congested and edematous and several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.

This lesion is called a malignant pustule.

The disease used to be common in dock workers, carrying loads of hides and skins on their bare backs and hence known as hide porter’s disease.

Cutaneous Anthrax generally resolves spontaneously, but 10 – 20% of untreated patients may develop fatal septicaemia or meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can result in an abnormality of the structure marked as "A"?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the nail matrix. Nail matrix abnormality can result in true leukonychia and reflects systemic disorders like thallium poisoning, arsenic poisoning, or septicemia.

The various parts of the nail include:

  • Nail plate: Durable, chemically resistant, partially translucent keratinized structure which grows throughout life.
  • Proximal nail fold: Cutaneous folded structure providing a visible proximal border of nail fold, continuous with the cuticle.
  • Lateral nail fold: Cutaneous folded structures providing the lateral borders to the nail.
  • Lunula: Convex margin of intermediate nail matrix seen through the nail.
  • Eponychium: Small band of epithelium extending from the proximal nail fold and adhering to the dorsal aspect of the nail plate.
  • Cuticle: Thin layer of dead tissue which forms a seal between the nail plate and eponychium to prevent pathogens from infecting the matrix area.
  • Nail Bed: The vascular bed upon which nail rests extending from the lunula to the hyponychium.
  • Hyponychium: Cutaneous margin underlying free nail, bordered distally by the distal groove.

Given below is a labelled image of the structure of a nail.

 

Leukonychia can be true or apparent.

  • True leukonychia is when there is a white discolouration of the nail due to nail matrix abnormalities. It can be due to:
    • True hereditary leukonychia: Milky porcelain white nails which may affect the nail in whole (total) or partial (subtotal). In subtotal leukonychia, the nail may be pink in the distal one third.
    • Mees lines/ True leukonychia/ Transverse leukonychia is 1-2 mm single or multiple white transverse bands, in the arcuate form of the lunula. They reflect systemic disorders like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning or septicemia.

Given below is an image of Mee's lines.

    • Punctate leukonychia: Contains white spots of 1–3 mm diameter as a result of minor matrix trauma like that in a manicure. It is also seen in alopecia areata.
    • Longitudinal leukonychia: Occurs due to a parakeratotic focus in the nail matrix, as seen in Darier's disease.

 

Given below is an image of nails in Darier's disease.

    • Striate leukonychia: Due to an unclear single cause. It could be described as a condition between Mees’ lines and punctate leukonychia, seen in alopecia areata and chemotherapy.
  • Apparent leukonychia: Occurs due to the changes in the nail bed, indicating anaemia, edema or vascular impairment. It may classified into:
    • Terry’s nails: Proximally white and distally normal nails which are attributed to mild increase in vascularity as seen in cirrhosis, congestive cardiac failure or diabetes.
    • Half‐and‐half nails: Occurs due to an increase in vessel wall thickness and melanin deposition, resulting in a proximal white zone and distal sharp, brownish demarcation, as seen in chronic renal failure or after chemotherapy.
    • Neapolitan nails: Bands of white, brown and red, which could be possibly due to old age.
    • Muehrcke’s white bands:  Paired bands parallel to the lunula, with pink between two white lines. They are commonly seen in hypoalbuminaemia. Reversal can occur after albumin correction.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

questions.text: A young woman presented with complaints of dysphagia, recurrent abdominal pain associated with nausea, feeling of 'hardness' over the left hypochondrium for the past 2 years. She reports that she is constantly worried about her symptoms. She has had multiple hospital visits, where detailed workups were not able to find any cause of her symptoms. She looks anxious with irritable affect. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the scenario, the presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder.

Somatic symptoms and related disorders group in DSM-5:

  • Somatic symptom disorder (somatoform disorder)
  • Illness anxiety disorder
  • Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder)
  • Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome)

Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months.

It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

DSM-5 criteria for the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder: 

  • One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life.
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associ­ated health concerns as manifested by at least one of the following:
    • Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one’s symptoms.
    • Persistently high level of anxiety about health or symptoms.
    • Excessive time and energy are devoted to these symptoms or health concerns.
  • Although a single somatic symptom may not be continuously present, the state of be­ing symptomatic is persistent.
  • The belief cannot have the intensity of a delusion, as seen in a delusional disorder, and cannot be restricted to distress about appearance, as seen in a body dysmorphic disorder.

The disorder follows an episodic course separated by long qui­escent periods. Exacerbations of somatic symptoms are associated with psychosocial stressors.

Patients with somatic symptom disorder usually resist psychi­atric treatment. Management involves:

  • Group psychotherapy - provides social support and interaction, helping to reduce anxiety
  • Other psychotherapy - insight-ori­ented psychotherapy, behavior therapy, cognitive therapy, and hypnosis, may be useful
  • Regularly scheduled physical examinations - to reassure patients that they are being taken care of
  • Invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedures should only be under­ taken, however, when objective evidence is present.
  • The clinician should refrain from treating equivocal or incidental physical examination findings.
  • Pharmacotherapy is used for treating somatic symptom disorder only when a patient has an underlying anxiety disorder or depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Illness anxiety disorder deals with the fear of having a disease rather than a concern about many symptoms. Patients with illness anxiety disorder primarily concerned about being sick

Option B: Delusional disorder beliefs occur in schizo­phrenia and other psychotic disorders. They deal with bizarre, idiosyncratic delusions along with the presence of other psychotic symptoms.

Option C: Factitious disorder refers to the intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with the goal to assume the sick role. 

Related Pearl: Classification of somatic symptom disorders: DSM-5 vs ICD-10

DSM-5

Conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) Dissociative (conversion) disorder
Illness anxiety disorder Hypochondriacal disorder

disorders category)

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

(functional neurologic symptom disorder)

Neurologic symptom  incompatible with any known neurologic disease, often acute onset associated with stress

Factitious disorder

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and is started on propranolol. After some days, he is brought to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing. He says that he is a smoker and has had difficulty breathing for the past several years. However, it has worsened after taking propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing difficulty is
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of respiratory difficulty in the patient have worsened after the intake of propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing is β2 blockade. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and prevents bronchodilation. Therefore, it should not be given to patients who have asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Other important side effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular system- 
    • Beta blockade decreases myocardial contractility. Therefore, it can exacerbate decompensated heart failure.
    • Decreased heart rate- Bradycardia, In patients with heart block it can cause fatal bradyarrhythmias
    • Abrupt discontinuation of β receptor antagonists after long-term treatment can exacerbate angina
  • Respiratory system- bronchospasm due to blockade of β2 receptors in the bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Central nervous system- fatigue, sleep disturbances, and depression.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease occurs due to the blockade of β2 receptors in the vascular smooth muscles.
  • It can slow the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia as they inhibit catecholamine-mediated glycogenolysis.
  • This class of drugs is also known to mask the hypoglycemia symptoms in diabetic patients. The symptoms of hypoglycemia which are mediated by the adrenaline release will be masked as beta-blockers will not allow adrenaline to react and interact with its beta 1 receptor.  
  • Hyperkalemia- blockade of β2 receptors prevents the entry of extracellular potassium into the cells.
  • Sexual dysfunction in males
  • They can also alter the serum triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol concentrations. Beta-blockers such as atenolol, metoprolol, and propranolol increase the levels of triglycerides and decrease the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Other beta-blockers like labetalol, pindolol, and acebutolol do not have any effect on lipid levels.

Autonomic innervation of the lung.

Relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles is brought by β2 receptors. Contraction is by the M2 and M3 cholinergic receptors. Therefore, important drugs that used for bronchodilation are 

  • β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc,
  • Antimuscarinic agents like ipratropium bromide, tiotropium, aclidinium, and umeclidinium.

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It acts equal affinity to both β1 and β2 receptors. It does not have intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and does not block α receptors.

Important adverse effects of propranolol are:

Cardiovascular system- It can cause or exacerbate heart failure in patients with compensated heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, or cardiomegaly. In patients with partial or complete AV conduction defects, β antagonists may cause life-threatening bradyarrhythmias. Sudden discontinuation of beta-blockers after prolonged use can exacerbate angina and may increase the risk of sudden death.

Respiratory system- It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and can cause bronchospasm.

Nervous system- It causes fatigue, sleep disturbances (including insomnia and nightmares), and depression.

Metabolism- It delays the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

Overdosage may lead to hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction, and widened QRS complexes, seizures, depression, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: During an experiment, it was found that a skeletal muscle's latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period were 15 ms, 30 ms, and 60 ms, respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency.
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 33 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanizing frequency = 1/30 per millisecond = 1/0.03 per second = 1000/30 per second = 33 per second.

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types, complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fiber before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe?
questions.solution:
Image 3 (Superior quadrantanopia) demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe.

Superior quadrantanopia in image 3 (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations, which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop.

Image 1: Bilateral hemianopia occurs due to a defect in the optic tract.

Image 2: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) defect is due to the involvement of superior fibers of the optic radiations – Baum’s loop. It is seen in parietal lobe lesions.

Image 4: Right contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to a defect in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The fontanelle marked “C” usually closes within  ________  after birth.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "C" is sphenoid fontanelle and it closes at around 2-3 months of age.

Fontanelle of the skull:

  • The anterior fontanelle is present between the two frontal and two parietal bones. It closes at around 18 - 24 months. The junction is marked by bregma where the coronal and sagittal sutures meet.
  • The posterior fontanelle is present between the junction of the sagittal and lambdoid suture and closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The sphenoid fontanelle corresponds to the pterion and also closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The mastoid fontanelle closes around the end of the first year.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test, which reveals the findings as shown in the image given below. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Marcus Gunn pupil, which is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve/cranial nerve II disease.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a RAPD or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The image given below shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex - On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect - Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil -In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Adie’s tonic pupil - In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: During histology class, you are asked to identify the various epithelia and their locations in the body. Which of the following parts of the urethra is lined by the epithelium shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, which is identified by the variations in the cell layers: the deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells, and, lastly, the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched, it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of recurrent seizures since childhood. EEG was normal and imaging of brain was done with the findings given below. What is the mode of inheritance of her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
History of recurrent seizures and the MRI finding of multiple subependymal nodules in the periventricular region is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. It has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem neurocutaneous characterized by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis was classically described as presenting in childhood with a pathognomonic triad (Vogt triad) of seizures, intellectual disability, and adenoma sebaceum. However, some patients are asymptomatic and have no impaired disability. 

Neurological manifestation is the hallmark of the disease and is best clinched by MRI brain. The 4 characteristic findings seen in TSC are - 

i) Subependymal nodules: They are benign lesions seen on the lateral ventricular wall. When these lesions are calcified, they project into the ventricular cavity having a candle-drip appearance. They are mostly asymptomatic and are conservatively managed. However, they have the potential for neoplastic changes, and thus, routine screening is advised. 

ii) Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs): They are multiphytic tumors that grow and block the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid around the brain and cause hydrocephalus. It requires immediate neurosurgical intervention. Surgical resection should be performed for acutely symptomatic SEGA. For growing but otherwise asymptomatic SEGAs, either surgical resection or medical treatment with an mTOR inhibitor (everolimus) may be used. 

iii) Cortical tubers are a common finding of TSC and are triangular-shaped lesions centred at the cortex/juxtacortical, with apex orientated "inward" toward the ventricles

iv) Retinal lesions consist of two types: hamartomas (elevated mulberry lesions) and white depigmented patches (similar to the hypopigmented skin lesions)

Cutaneous lesions of the disease are demonstrated best by Wood lamp examination. The findings seen here are - 

  • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules 
  • Facial angiofibromas
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails
  • Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

Other system involvement:

i) Renal angiomyolipomas - benign tumors that can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. They usually do not require any intervention. mTOR inhibitors like everolimus can be used to decrease the size of the lesion. 

ii) Cardiac rhabdomyoma - detected by echocardiogram, usually by 20-30 wk gestation. The rhabdomyomas may be numerous and located throughout the ventricular myocardium, and although they can cause congestive heart failure and arrhythmias in a minority of patients, they tend to slowly resolve spontaneously. 

ii) Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis - the classic pulmonary lesion in TSC and only affects women. It can predispose to pulmonary infarction, hemorrhage, spontaneous pneumothorax, fibrosis etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in catalysing the formation of phosphodiester bonds during the repair of the DNA damaged due to reactive oxygen species?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, the enzyme involved in catalyzing the formation of phosphodiester bonds during the repair of the DNA damaged due to reactive oxygen species is DNA ligase.

All DNA repair systems use a ligase to seal breaks in the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. Although polymerase enzymes make phosphodiester bonds during DNA synthesis, these enzymes do not ligate strands of DNA.

questions.text: A 25-year old gymnast presented with a history of fatigue, amenorrhea and dizziness for the past 5 months. She is found to have a BMI of 17 kg/m2. She is particularly concerned about gaining weight and mentions having a calorie-restricted diet. Any of the following may be seen in association with her underlying condition except?
questions.solution:
The above scenario showing weakness, amenorrhea with food restriction, and the fear of gaining weight with a BMI of 17 kg/m² is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. Hypercholesterolemia, not hypo, is seen in anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder in which the patient has an intense fear of becoming fat. This fear leads to restriction of calorie intake resulting in significantly reduced body weight. The patient does not understand the seriousness of the reduced body weight and continues to restrict food intake. Some patients might also have a history of self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas.

Anorexia nervosa is associated with depression, social phobia, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Other conditions associated with anorexia include anxiety disorders, panic disorder, and substance abuse/dependence.

Diagnosis is based on the presence of 3 essential criteria:

  • Behavior: Poor eating habits leading to significant weight loss for age.
  • Psychopathology: Fear of gaining weight, with a distorted perception of body weight
  • Physiological symptomatology: Presence of medical signs and symptoms from starvation

Types include:

  • Restrictive - No episodes of binge eating or purging behavior in the past 3 months
  • Purge/Binge-eating - Episodes of binge-eating and/or purging behavior in the past 3 months.

Patients with anorexia are often secretive, deny their symptoms and resist treatment. They are usually brought for medical opinion by a person concerned about their weight loss.

Clinical features include:

  • Low BMI
  • Fracture in a young patient after trivial trauma - suggestive of osteoporosis
  • Soft fine hair on the trunk - lanugo hair that occurs due to starvation
  • Amenorrhea
  • Bilateral parotid swelling - due to purging
  • Decreased tolerance to cold
  • Peripheral edema due to starvation

The level of severity can be classified according to the BMI:

Level of severity BMI (kg/m2)
Mild >=17
Moderate <17
Severe <16
Extreme <15

Lab findings in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count- leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte- hypokalemic alkalosis (purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose- often low (emaciated phase)
  • Serum salivary amylase- often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG- ST-segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • Low LH and FSH
  • High serum cholesterol level - increased LDL levels due to thyroid hormone changes and increased lipolysis
  • Increased GH levels
  • Prerenal azotemia
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

Treatment of anorexia nervosa:

  • Hospitalization: 
    • Patients with weight 20% less than expected weight for height should be considered for hospitalization. 
    • Dur­ing a hospitalized treatment program, patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
    • The daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
    • If vomiting is occurring, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.
    • Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.
  • Psychotherapy: 
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Dynamic psychotherapy
    • Family therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment but cypro­heptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorproma­zine show some improvement in these patients.
    • Trials of fluoxetine have resulted in some reports of weight gain.

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in red color, in the image below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is sigmoid sulcus.

  • The sigmoid sulcus is a wide groove, present anteriorly, in the mastoid part of the temporal bone.
  • It contains the sigmoid sinus.
  • Superiorly the sigmoid sulcus is continuous with the transverse sulcus.
  • Inferiorly, it crosses the occipitomastoid suture and grooves the jugular process of the occipital bone.

Other options:

Option a:  Pre-chiasmatic sulcus (also called chiasmatic groove or optic groove) is a transverse groove in the sphenoid bone, between the optic canals. The optic chiasma lies over the pre-chiasmatic sulcus.

Option c: Carotid sulcus is a shallow groove in the lateral wall of the body of the sphenoid. It contains the internal carotid artery.

Option d: Transverse sulcus is the groove for transverse sinus in the occipital bone, as shown below.

questions.text: The USG of the gall bladder of a forty-year-old obese female patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography of the gallbladder shows acoustic shadow, indicating the presence of stone in the gallbladder (cholelithiasis).

Cholelithiasis is commonly seen in women. Over 70% of the gallstones are composed of cholesterol, while the pigment gallstones composed of calcium carbonate constitute most of the remaining 30%.

Radiological features:

X-ray: Only calcified stones are visible.

Ultrasonography:

  • The gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast acoustic shadow. Stone mobility may be demonstrated, if it is not impacted.
  • In contrast, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow.
  • In gallbladder full of stones, there is a dense acoustic shadowing with the presence of two parallel curved echogenic lines separated by a thin anechoic space. This characteristic appearance is referred to as ‘Double-arc shadow sign’, or wall-echo-shadow sign.

The image-below shows wall-echo-shadow sign due to the presence of a large gall stone.

Other options:

Option A: Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall. The image below shows calcification in the gall bladder wall(on CT) suggestive of a porcelain gall bladder.

 

Option B: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. The image below shows a gallbladder polyp on USG:

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: Punishment for infanticide comes under:
questions.solution:
In India, infanticide is considered as murder and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Option C: IPC 304A – Punishment for Rash or Negligent Homicide. If death of a person is caused by any rash or negligent act, not amounting to culpable homicide, the punishment is imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine or both.

Option D: IPC 306 – Punishment for abetment of suicide.

Other relevant sections:

  • Section 317 IPC – Abandoning the foetus.
  • Section 318 IPC – Concealment of birth.

questions.text:
A child was brought to the primary health center for vaccination. The parents informed the medical officer that the child had a history of egg allergy. Which of the following vaccines can not be given to the child?
  1. Yellow fever
  2. Japanese encephalitis
  3. Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  4. Influenza
  5. Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, yellow fever and influenza vaccines cannot be given to a child who has an egg allergy.

Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are prepared in hen's egg tissues. Hence, they cannot be given to a patient with a history of anaphylactic reactions following egg ingestion. However, vaccine viruses propagated in chicken fibroblast cells like measles or MMR vaccines can be given.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can lead to this condition?

Platelet count - 37,000/μL

Bleeding time - 16 minutes

PT - 13 seconds

aPTT - 30 seconds

Peripheral blood smear - megathrombocytes
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:

  • Bleeding tendency - petechiae
  • Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time
  • Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis
  • Female preponderance
  • Absence of splenomegaly

 Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a mine worker who died of cardiac failure, reveals the following finding. Which of the following is characteristically associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image showing Aldrich-Mees lines are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Arsenic in its metallic form is not poisonous but when it unites with oxygen it forms poisonous vapors of arsenic trioxide. These interfere with cellular respiration damaging mitochondrial enzymes. It is present in fruit sprays, copper and gold mineral deposits, weed-killers, insecticides, rat poisons, wallpapers, and artificial flowers.

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1-3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy.
  • Marsh's and Reinsch's tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer),  BAL (British Anti Lewisite), and penicillamine can also be used. 

 

The images given below show the skin manifestations of arsenic poisoning.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

Skin

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with difficulty swallowing food and liquids for the last two months. She also complains of a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat. She has had an intermittent burning sensation in her throat and chest during the last month. Further evaluation with barium swallow shows the findings below. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: All patients with this condition should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions
Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature
Calcium channel blockers may be tried in mildly symptomatic patients
This condition is seen most often in female patients

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture and barium swallow showing a corkscrew appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Aperistalsis of the oesophageal body is a characteristic finding in achalasia cardia, not DES.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Esophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. This condition is seen most often in female patients

Clinical presentation:

  • Dysphagia for solids and liquids
  • The sensation of food stuck in the throat
  • Retrosternal, noncardiac chest pain as a solitary symptom or accompanying the dysphagia
  • Symptoms of heartburn or regurgitation

Investigations :

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. 

Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for DES is nonsurgical modalities with pharmacologic therapy or endoscopic intervention being preferred. All patients with DES should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions like anxiety, depression, psychosomatic complaints etc. Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP
Increased duration of peristalsis
Normal peristalsis
DCI>8000mmHg

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding pterygoid muscle are true.
  1. Pterygoid venous plexus lies around and within the medial pterygoid muscle
  2. Maxillary artery lies superficially over lateral pterygoid muscle
  3. Auriculotemporal branch of mandibular nerve passes between the two heads of lateral pterygoid muscle
  4. Medial pterygoid is innervated by the trunk of mandibular nerve
  5. Mandibular nerve branches are deep relations of lateral pterygoid muscle
questions.solution:
Pterygoid venous plexus lies around and within the lateral(not medial) pterygoid muscle and is important in the spread of infection. The buccal branch  of the mandibular nerve (not the auriculotemporal), passes between the two heads of the lateral pterygoid. 

Medial pterygoid:

It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of mandible/closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

Lateral pterygoid:

It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Important relations of lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • lies in roof of infratemporal fossa
  • deep relations - branches of mandibular nerve and main origin of medial pterygoid muscle
  • superficial relations - maxillary artery
  • buccal branch of the mandibular nerve passes between the two heads of the lateral pterygoid
  • medial pterygoid and lingual and inferior alveolar nerve emerges below the inferior border
  • deep temporal nerves and vessels emerge from its upper border
  • Pterygoid venous plexus - lies around and within the lateral pterygoid muscle and is important in the spread of infection.

Related Pearl: Muscles of mastication

Muscles Origin Insertion Action
Lateral pterygoid

Upper head - Infratemporal surface, sphenoid bone

Lower head - Lateral pterygoid plate

Upper head - Pterygoid fovea 

Lower head - TMJ capsule and articular disc

Depresses mandible (with suprahyoid muscles)

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(Side to side) movements
Medial pterygoid

Superficial head - Maxilla

Deep head - Lateral pterygoid plate, Palatine bone

Angle of mandible

Ramus of mandible behind mandibular foramen

Elevates mandible  

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(side to side) movements
Temporalis

Temporal fossa

Temporal fascia

Ramus of mandible

Coronoid process

Elevates mandible

Side-to-side movements

Jaw retraction
Masseter Zygomatic arch Ramus of mandible

Elevates mandible

Jaw protrusion

questions.text:
Match the lupus nephritis lesions with their treatments.
1. Focal Lupus Nephritis a. Only supportive treatment, no specific therapy
2. Membranous Lupus Nephritis b. A short course of high-dose corticosteroids
3. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis c. Hemodialysis
4. Advanced Sclerosing Lupus Nephritis d. Corticosteroids+ Immunosuppressants +/- ACEs/ARBs
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus, seen in about 30-50% of patients with SLE. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Management of lupus nephritis:

  • Class I (minimal mesangial) and II lesions (mesangial proliferative): They are associated with minimal or no symptoms and have an excellent prognosis. They do not require any therapy. 
  • Class III lesions (focal lupus nephritis): They are associated with few symptoms and a good prognosis. Management includes the administration of a short course of high-dose corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.
  • Class IV lesions (diffuse lupus nephritis): Manifestations include hematuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and renal casts. Treatment includes the administration of high-dose steroids combined with either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil for 2–6 months. It is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine.
  • Class V lesions (membranous lupus nephritis): They are associated with severe manifestations and a poor prognosis. Management includes the administration of steroids in combination with other immunosuppressive agents. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system may be administered to attenuate proteinuria.
  • Class VI lesions (advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis): They present with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and require hemodialysis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: If a drug follows first-order kinetics, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours when a patient is given 300 mg drug of which 120 mg is excreted in 90 min?
questions.solution:
The amount of drug remaining in the body after 6 hours following an initial administration of 300mg of the drug is 38mg.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

120 mg of 300 mg is excreted in 90 minutes ---> 120/300 = 0.40 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 300 mg-120 mg = 180 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 180 * 0.4 = 72 mg is eliminated and 180-72 = 108 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 108 * 0.4 = 43.2 mg is eliminated and 108-43.2 = 64.8 remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 64.8 * 0.4 = 25.92 mg is eliminated and 64.80-25.92 = 38.88 mg remains after 6 hours. 

A simpler way to calculate 

  • 2/5 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes → 3/5 remains after 90 minutes.
  • 6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.
  • So 300 * (3/5)(3/5)(3/5)(3/5) = 38.88 mg remains after 360 minutes 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: All of the following cause a left shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve except -
questions.solution:
Body temperature of 39 degrees celsius (hyperthermia) causes a right shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve. 

The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2. It is normally sigmoid in shape. If the oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less which favours O2 delivery. This means a higher P50, means higher PO2 is required to maintain 50% saturation (R - Right shift Releases oxygen). If the curve is shifted to the left, it means that affinity has increased for O2 ( which favours O2 binding ) i.e. lower P50 value. ( L-Left shift Leashes oxygen )

 Causes for the right shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2
  • Exercise

Causes for the left shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

Bohr's effect - The decrease in O2 affinity of haemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls.

Haldane effect - Increased capacity of deoxygenated haemoglobin to bind and carry CO2.

questions.text: A child presents with perianal itching, which occurs predominantly at night and disturbs sleep. The eggs of the causative organism have been shown in the given image. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection.

Infection with Enterobius vermicularis presents with perianal itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus).

Plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo, are deposited by the gravid female worm on perianal skin which causes pruritis.

Diagnosis: 

  • Microscopic examination of adhesive cellophane tape pressed against the perianal region early in the morning frequently demonstrates eggs.
  • A digital rectal examination may also be used to obtain samples for a wet mount.
  • Routine stool samples rarely demonstrate Enterobius ova.

Treatment: 

  • Albendazole 400 mg PO with a repeat dose 2 weeks
  • Frequent changing of underclothes, bedclothes, and bedsheets decreases environmental egg contamination and may decrease the risk for autoinfection.
  • Good hand hygiene is the most effective method of prevention.
The image given below shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are derived from the 4th aortic arch?
  1. Arch of aorta
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Brachiocephalic artery
  4. Right Subclavian artery
  5. Left Subclavian artery
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1 and 4 only.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side: Part of the arch of aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side: Proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

The proximal part of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th aortic arch. The distal segment of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right dorsal aorta and the 7th intersegmental artery. 

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to follow-up and is brought to you 2 years later. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years old, posteromedial soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line of management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with the type of microabscesses seen in them:
Disease Type of microabscess
1. Mycosis fungoides a. Neutrophilic
2. Psoriasis vulgaris b. Mixed
3. Pemphigus vegetans c. Lymphocytic
4. Dermatitis herpetiformis d. Eosinophilic
questions.solution:
The rightly matched diseases with the type of microabscesses seen in them are:

Disease Type of microabscess
1. Mycosis fungoides c. Lymphocytic
2. Psoriasis vulgaris a. Neutrophilic
3. Pemphigus vegetans d. Eosinophilic
4. Dermatitis herpetiformis b. Mixed
 
A microabscess is a focal accumulation of polymorphs, lymphoid cells, or eosinophils in the epidermis, adnexal structures, or mucous membranes.
 
Microabscesses can be classified according to the predominant cell types seen:
 
Type of predominant cell Diseases
Neutrophilic

- Psoriasis vulgaris
- Reiter's syndrome
- Pustular drug eruptions
- Geographical tongue
- Impetigo
- Pustular secondary syphilis
- Granuloma inguinale
- Fungal infections: Candidiasis, dermatophytosis
Lymphocytic - Allergic contact dermatitis
- Mycosis fungoides
- Pityriasis rosea
Eosinophilic - Eosinophilic pustular folliculitis
- Pemphigus vegetans
- Incontinenta pigmenti
Mixed (neutrophilic and eosinophilic)

- Dermatitis herpetifomis
- Epidermolysis bullosa
- Bullous form of lupus eythematosis
 
Microabscesses can be:
  • Epidermal:
    • Polymorphonuclear:
      • Psoriasis (Munroe's microabscess)
      • Candidiasis
    • Lymphocytic:
      • Mycosis fungoides (Pautrier's microabscess)
  • Dermal:
    • Dermetitis herpetiformis (Papillary tip microabscess)
    • Vasculitis
    • Infections like furuncle and cellulitis
Named microabscesses are:
 
Munro's microabscesses are neutrophilic microabscesses that are found in the stratum corneum. They are seen in chronic psoriasis along with features of irregular epidermal thickening and parakeratosis.

Pautrier's microabscesses are intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscesses characteristically seen in mycosis fungoides. The cells within the epidermis may show nuclear hyperchromatism or atypia.

Papillary tip microabscesses are mixed microabscesses that contain neutrophils and some eosinophils in the tips of the dermal papillae. They are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and bullous eruptions like epidermolysis bullosa and the bullous form of lupus erythematosus.

The image below shows papillary neutrophil microabscesses in case of dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text: The graph shows the percentage of filtered load remaining at various levels of nephrons for different substances. Select the correct options for inulin, alanine, and PAH respectively.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows the substances which are freely filtered (C - inulin), freely filtered and secreted additionally from tubules (D - PAH), and substances that are filtered very little and reabsorbed subsequently (A - alanine).

The given graph basically measures the amount (not concentration) of a particular substance in renal tubules after it undergoes ultrafiltration. 

Substances like inulin which are freely filtered (100%) are labelled with C. It further doesn't undergo any reabsorption or secretion. It is hence a straight line i.e., its concentration doesn't change throughout the length of the nephron.

Substances like PAH which are freely filtered and further secreted are labelled with D. This is because its concentration keeps increasing throughout the length of the nephron due to secretion into tubules.

Substances like amino acids or glucose are not freely filtered. And in normal conditions, they are almost completely reabsorbed. Hence they have a graph that is sloping down. And since they are completely reabsorbed within PCT itself, their concentration is not detected after proximal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: The incidence rate of lung cancer is 120/100,000 person-years for smokers and 10/100,000 person-years for nonsmokers. The prevalence of smoking is 20% in the community. If the prevalence of smoking in the community was decreased to 10%, the excess incidence rate of lung cancer that could be averted in that community would be?
questions.solution:
If the prevalence of smoking was reduced to 10%, 11/100,000 excess cases of lung cancer due to smoking could be averted.

We can calculate this by using the population attributable risk (PAR) = (attributable risk) x (prevalence of exposure in the population).

The relative risk is defined as the incidence rate among the exposed (Ie) divided by the incidence rate among the nonexposed (Io).
In this case, (120/100,000)/(10/100,000) = 12.

The attributable risk (AR) is defined as Ie − Io = (120/100,000) − (10/100,000) = 110/100,000.
The attributable risk percentage is equal to [(Ie − Io) / Ie] × 100 = (110/100,000)/(120/100,000) = 92%.

If the prevalence of smoking in the population is 20%, then the PAR is calculated as follows:

    AR × prevalence of exposure = 110/100,00 × 20/100 = 22/100,000.

If the prevalence of smoking is 10%, then

    AR × prevalence of exposure = 110/100,000 × 10/100 = 11/100,000.

Therefore, excess incidence rate of lung cancer that can be avoided is (22/100,000) - (11/100,000) = (11/100,000)

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with oral ulcers and bullae over the mucosa and skin. On examination, the bullae are flaccid and filled with clear fluid. Histopathology of the lesion shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

Variants of pemphigus:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vegetans
  • Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
  • Pemphigus erythematosus
  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A patient presents with cystocele and rectocele. Which level of uterine support is likely to be damaged as per the DeLancey classification?
questions.solution:
Damage to DeLancey level II structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Level II supports mainly consist of pubocervical fascia anteriorly, rectovaginal fascia (along with septum) posteriorly, and paracolpos (vascular and connective tissue structures present beside the cervix). As the name suggests, pubocervical fascia connects the cervix to the posterior surface of the pubic bone. The rectovaginal septum separates the rectum from the vagina and cervix of the uterus. Together, these structures form a supportive sling that helps maintain the position of the bladder and rectum. Therefore, damage to these structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: X linked Sphingolipidosis presenting with telangiectatic skin lesions, kidney failure and acroparesthesia will have ________________
questions.solution:
The only X-linked sphingolipidosis is Fabry disease. It is caused due to deficiency of alpha-galactosidase deficiency.

It presents with telangiectatic skin lesions, kidney failure, corneal opacity, acroparesthesia, and Fabry crisis (agonizing, burning pain in the extremities). Pain is the most debilitating symptom in childhood and adolescence.

There is an accumulation of globosides in the brain, heart, kidneys, and skin. It is treated by recombinant human enzyme replacement therapy.

Other options:

Beta-galactosidase deficiency is found in Krabbe disease.

Beta glucocerebrosidase deficiency is found in Gaucher's disease.

Ceramidase deficiency is found in Farber's disease.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: The true statement regarding the clinical condition seen in the image shown below?

choices.text: It is caused by adenovirus 3, 4, and 7
It is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus
It belongs to 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging
Oral tetracycline is the drug of choice.

questions.solution:
The above image identified as the cicatrizing stage of trachoma belongs to the 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging.

Regarding other options:

  • Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus 3, 4 and 7.
  • Mucus fishing syndrome is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus.
  • Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in trachoma.

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.
