questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A 76-year-old man was admitted with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. His relatives said that he had a similar episode 3 months back. His drug history includes aspirin 75mg, telmisartan 20mg, metformin 500mg, glimepiride 2gm and atorvastatin 40mg. What should be the LDL target for this patient according to the European Society of Cardiology 2019 guidelines?
questions.solution:
Though this patient comes under very high-cardiovascular risk category according to the European Society of Cardiology 2019 guidelines, he has had a recurrent acute coronary syndrome while being on a lipid-lowering drug (atorvastatin). Hence, according to this guideline, the target value of LDL is 40 mg/dL, not 55mg/dL.

The various cardiovascular risk categories according to the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) or European Atherosclerosis Society (EAS) 2019 guidelines -

Categories

Diseases

 Target LDL levels for therapy
Very high-risk

Any one of the following:

  • Documented/non-documented atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD)
  • Diabetes mellitus with target organ damage
  • Early-onset type-I diabetes mellitus with more than 20 years duration
  • Severe chronic kidney disease
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia with a history of ASCVD

55 mg/dL
High-risk
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia without major risk factors
  • Diabetes mellitus without target organ damage
  • Diabetes mellitus less than 10 years duration
  • Moderate chronic kidney disease

 

 70 mg/dL
Moderate-risk

Young patients with diabetes mellitus of less than 10 years duration

100 mg/dL
Low-risk Others 160 mg/dL


The target LDL level for patients who have recurrent ASCVD (atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease) while on lipid-lowering drugs is 40mg/dL.

ASCVD includes:

  • Previous acute coronary syndrome - MI or unstable angina
  • Stable angina
  • Coronary revascularisation
  • Stroke
  • Transient ischaemic attack
  • >50% stenosis on coronary angiogram

 

According to the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) or European Atherosclerosis Society (EAS) 2019 guidelines -

  • "Treating to meet LDL target value" forms the core of the guidelines. This means that only LDL has been proven to be associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular changes. And reducing LDL has been proven to have the maximum benefit in preventing or treating this disease.
  • High levels of triglycerides are not a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Hence, reducing triglyceride levels has no benefit in preventing or treating cardiovascular disease. (Triglyceride values up to 440mg/dL are reported to be safe, and values above 880mg/dL are proven to cause pancreatitis.)
  • Type 1 and type 5 dyslipidemias have been proven to have no cardiovascular disease risk.
  • Increasing HDL levels have proven to be of no benefit in preventing or treating cardiovascular disease or reducing the mortality rate.

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine for yellow fever is given subcutaneously. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.text:
A pregnant lady has undergone a glucose tolerance test according to IADPSG guidelines. The blood glucose levels were found to be 90mg/dL, 173mg/dL, and 135mg/dL at fasting, 1-hr and 2-hr of glucose administration respectively. What is the most appropriate next step in this case?

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel

choices.text: Advise her only regular exercises as the values are normal
Start her on a diabetic diet

questions.solution:
The test performed here is a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) according to the IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel) guidelines. It is a single-step diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. Blood glucose levels are checked at fasting, and after the first and second hour of administering the glucose. As none of the values meets the IADPSG criteria, this patient is normal and needs no further evaluation. Hence, she is advised to continue her regular exercises.

Gestational diabetes is defined as carbohydrate intolerance of varying severity that is diagnosed in pregnancy. It presents in the second, or most commonly in the third trimester. It is not seen in the first trimester. It usually resolves within 6 weeks of delivery.

It occurs due to the combined effect of HPL (human placental lactogen), estrogen, progesterone, free cortisol and also due to the degradation of the insulin by the placenta. All these hormonal changes lead to an increase in insulin demand as the pregnancy advances. The insulin resistance is found to be the maximum at 24 to 28 weeks of gestation, hence this condition is never seen in the first trimester.

OGTT (oral glucose tolerance test) is done twice during the antenatal period.

  • In the first trimester - to detect overt diabetes
  • Then between 24-28 weeks period of gestation (POG) - to detect gestational diabetes.

 

Criteria / Guidelines ACOG IADPSG DIPSI
Followed in USA USA India
Number of steps 2 steps - OGCT & OGTT 1 step - OGTT 1 step - OGTT
Amount of glucose for screening test/ OGCT 50 g without prior fasting;    
≥ 140 mg/ dL after 1 hour qualifies for OGTT - -  
Amount of glucose for diagnostic test/ OGTT 100 g 75 g 75 g
Fasting for OGTT yes yes no
Fasting value < 95 mg/dL < 92 mg/dL -
1-hr OGTT < 180 mg/dL < 180 mg/dL -
2-hr OGTT < 155mg/dL < 153 mg/dL ≥ 140mg/ dL - gestational diabetes ; ≥ 200 mg/dL - overt diabetes
3-hr OGTT < 140 mg/dL - -
Diagnosed as diabetes when ≥ 2 values exceed or is equal (Carpenter-Coustan criteria used above) ≥ 1 value(s) exceeds or is equal ≥ 140mg/ dL - gestational diabetes ; ≥ 200 mg/dL - overt diabetes

DIPSI- Diabetes In Pregnancy Study Group India

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel

ACOG- American College of Obstetrics & Gynaecology

OGCT- Oral glucose challenge test

OGTT- Oral glucose tolerance test

 

Once diagnosed with gestational diabetes, a diabetic diet is advised for 2 weeks. At the end of 2 weeks, a 2-hr OGTT is done. If the blood glucose level is <120 mg/dL, the diabetic diet is continued. If ≥ 120 mg/dL, insulin is started. Regular insulin and NPH is preferred. But if the patient refuses to take insulin, only then oral hypoglycaemic agents (OHAs) like metformin or glyburide can be used.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a child, you notice the following peculiar ocular finding. This is termed as:
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the color of one iris differs from the other, i.e different colors of the two iris. This is called Heterochromia iridum

questions.text: A 58-year-old female was diagnosed with a large pituitary mass on MRI scanning. The presence of high circulating levels of which of the following hormones avoids the need for surgical resection of the pituitary gland?
questions.solution:
Circulating prolactin levels should always be assessed in cases of pituitary adenomas, as the presence of high prolactin levels indicates prolactinoma, which can be treated with dopamine agonists, thereby avoiding unnecessary surgical resection.

Dopamine agonists are first-line therapy in most patients with prolactinoma. Commonly used dopamine agonists include bromocriptine, cabergoline, and quinagolide.

Dopamine agonists reduce serum prolactin concentration and cause a significant reduction in the tumor size after several months of therapy. If the patient has any visual defects due to tumor suppression effects, they tend to improve within a few days after the administration of dopamine agonists.

Prolonged use of ergot-derived dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline may cause fibrotic reactions in the heart due to interaction with 5-HT2B receptors. These effects are mostly seen in patients with Parkinson's disease. Hence, if prolonged treatment is required, then non-ergot agents such as quinagolide are indicated.

In patients who achieve normoprolactinemia and significant reduction of the tumor mass, the dopamine agonist can be withdrawn after two years of therapy.

Note that surgical decompression is usually necessary only when a macroprolactinoma does not respond adequately to dopamine agonist therapy.

questions.text: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.solution:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.

Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.  

HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication.

Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

HBV infection in the recent past
